In April 1607, three Virginia Company ships sailed into Chesapeake Bay under the command of Captain Christopher Newport. They made landfall on the southernmost peninsula in the bay, naming it Cape Henry in honour of the Prince of Wales. Life for the early settlers was far from easy, even though they ruled themselves.\\n\\nNewport returned to England for supplies, leaving Captain John Smith, an acquitted mutineer, in charge. With limited food supplies, the constant presence of disease, and the danger of attack by the native tribes, many of the settlers perished within a few months of reaching the New World.\\n\\nIf this new community is to flourish they will need food, in the shape of farms and fisheries. A cash crop like tobacco will prove the financial viability of the colony to those back home in England and much-needed income for the settlers. Complacency, however, is dangerous. The native tribes remain a threatâ€¦

The French and Indian Wars began as the result of British and French rivalries in North America, and were part of a larger, globe-spanning conflict between the two nations. In 1754 both countries wanted control of the Ohio Valley, an uncharted but potentially valuable area. Each built a chain of forts into the valley to stake their claims, and conflict was inevitable, as struggles between native tribes were used to foment further trouble.\\n\\nThe war was a tough experience for the British. Both sides quickly realised that alliances with local tribes would be an asset. The French were better at using the North American terrain to their advantage, and early clashes saw heavy British losses. However, it was during this conflict that a young officer called George Washington began his military career.\\n\\nTo secure America, the British must remove the French threat. Take control of the Ohio Valley. Fort Niagara must be in British hands if an attack on the southern fort of Louisburg is to succeed, and allow a campaign northwards to Quebec and MontrÃ©al.

In 1775 a storm is brewing in America. Following the end of the French and Indian Wars, many people in the Thirteen Colonies are increasingly incensed by the British. Laws and new taxes are being imposed from London, and â€œseditious talkâ€ of revolution is no longer a whisper.\\n\\nDiscontent is widespread, but it is not until a morning in April, 1775 that talk becomes warfare. In Lexington, a group of British soldiers open fire on local militiamen. This skirmish, the Battle of Lexington and Concord, saw the first shots fired in a conflict that would split families, divide friends, and tear apart an empire.\\n\\nAnd so the fight for Americaâ€™s freedom has truly begun. Until the British are removed from the Thirteen Colonies Americans shall never be truly free. If the British Army is to be driven out, the Americans will need help. Allying yourself with the enemies of the British could provide the experienced troops required to remove them from America once and for all.

The United States of America is a nation forged in the fires of revolution and rebellion against a British monarch seen as distant, foreign and tyrannical.\\n\\nAfter the French and Indian Wars, the British government took an entirely unreasonable line: the American colonists should pay taxes to contribute to the navy and army that helped defend them. After all, those colonial fellows enjoyed the benefits of peace, protected by Britainâ€™s expensive soldiers and sailors. The colonists had other views. The British responded with political stupidity and military ineptitude.\\n\\nAided, once they had rebelled, by the French Bourbons (who, for reasons of their own, had every wish to see Britain pre-occupied with war and then humiliated by seditious rebels), the Americans faced down Britain. The struggle split counties, cities, towns, even families, but it united the nation.\\n\\nIn its wake, the revolution left a new kind of nation, a republic where men choose their own destinies, and are not subject to the whims of kings. This spirit of independence is a source of strength: it is an idea worth defending! It is also a source of weakness, for Americans cherish the right to do as they think best. This is not necessarily a good thing in an army.\\n\\nAmerica now has a future of boundless possibilities. A continent stretches away to the West, and no one is entirely sure what is to be found there. The Atlantic swell washes against the eastern seaboard, and beckons American seamen onwards: trade and adventure lie that way too. There may still be scores to settle with the British in Canada, or ambitious nations from Europe to discourage. There is much to do, if this newest and boldest of nations is to survive and prosper!
Episode I â€“ The Jamestown Colony
Episode II â€“ The French and Indian War
Episode III â€“ American War of Independence
United States â€“ A New Nation
This man does not normally demonstrate much skill when attacking an enemy fleet.
It would be better for everyone concerned if this man stayed locked in his cabin during any kind of naval attack.
A confused flatfish shows more aggression and skill than this admiral when attacking.
This admiral shows the skill to use his aggressive instincts to good advantage in battle.
This admiral has a talent for attacking and using the prevailing conditions to gain the advantage.
This admiral is a master of aggressive fleet actions, and almost swoons with the desire to attack!
This man has a clear grasp of naval tactics, and the controlled aggression to use them to brilliant effect.
With the wind at his back, no enemy fleet in the world can hold this national hero in check!
This man finds command of a rowing boat something of a trial.
Perhaps it is seasickness, but this man shows a little ineptitude when fighting at sea.
The handling of ships in battle is a talent that has so far eluded this admiral.
A man so conspicuously hopeless in command might be better employed feeding fish - as bait.
This man is a danger to his bath sponge, let alone any hapless sailors under his command.
This fellow displays strong command of the light, fast ships needed to break through a blockade of ships.
This fellow has shown remarkable skill and aplomb whilst smashing through enemy naval blockades.
This fellow confounds the enemy with the elusive speed and manoeuvrability of his expertly-controlled ships.
An admiral can employ techniques to prevent enemy ships breaking his blockade. This fellow knows many of them.
Due to his skill when blockading enemy ports, only a master blockade runner stands a chance against this man.
No one gets past this man, his line of ships is like a wall of steel to an enemy fleet.
This man may have heard of the art of public speaking, but he certainly doesn't believe it worth learning.
This man can inspire people to hurl themselves into the sea, mostly to get away from his awful rhetoric.
The sea is this man's first love, a good fight his second!
This man can read the wind and waves, so gaining an advantage in battle.
An innate understanding of the sea's moods give this man an advantage in any battle.
A steadying presence on the quarterdeck does much to make the men feel better.
This admiral laughs in the face of danger. Although he is obviously barking mad, his men love him for it.
The enemy, sir? Time's better spent in fearing kelp, barnacles, herring and... Andâ€¦my mother!
This man's name is a byword for courage throughout the fleet, and throughout the land fathers name their newborn sons after him!
Courage might as well be this man's middle name. Children, ships and city streets - along with houses of ill-repute and drinking dens - are named in his honour.
This man is more at home aboard ship than on his native soil.
Sent to sea almost as soon as he could walk, this man knows winds and tides as friends.
The siren song of the sea! Is there any other tune worth listening to for a true Briton?
When this man is discussed in polite society his tailor attracts more praise than his courage.
Rumours of this man's cowardice are quietly whispered - at least where he can hear them.
This admiral's cowardice is the subject of much bitter humour on the lower decks.
Cowardice is an ugly word, but it is the only one that will do.
This man has a talent for commanding smaller ships, and using them to advantage.
This man has a talent for running smaller ships, and making a profit into the bargain!
This man relishes the independence of smaller commands, and uses unrated ships to their full potential.
Naval combat when on the strategic defensive is not one of this man's strengths.
This admiral has comprehensively failed to understand how to fight a fleet when he is attacked.
There are ducks that have a better grasp of defensive naval tactics than this admiral.
This man has a good grasp of fleet handling when on the strategic defensive.
This admiral displays much skill when attacked and can find an advantage in wind and wave even when on the defensive.
This man has an almost-unmatched grasp of defensive naval tactics, and is rarely bested when attacked.
When attacked, this admiral's handling of any fleet action is decisive, masterly - and usually victorious!
This man's wine merchant is comfortably wealthy.
This man has an awesome capacity for strong drink with every meal, and between meals too.
A rum ration, sir? Bring me a bucket, and less of your insolence!
Strong spirits have entirely ruined this man: his mind is broken and his fortune is pissed away.
This man could find his way through any shoal waters or weather any storm, and never even spill his gin!
This man has an inherent air of command that gives confidence to his underlings.
The sea and its ways hold no mysteries for this man, and he fears nothing when afloat.
This man has a good grasp of naval tactics.
This man understands the business of sinking enemy ships.
This man has the talent to win sea battles, and has developed the habit of doing so.
Even the wind and waves seem to obey this man's commands, such is his mastery of naval combat.
Sailors under this man's command willingly set course for Hell, confident that he will bring them glory and prize money in equal measure!
Mockery is heaped upon this officer's efforts.
This man is seldom praised, often vilified, and given to kicking hacks into the sea.
He also has a rather unsatisfying 'smallholding', at, ahem, 'Breeches Manor', or so I'm toldâ€¦
The scales! The eyes! Fish know things: secrets from the deep mere men were never meant to fathom.
It's a very nice colour scheme for the fleet. I think it sits well with the  swivel gun napkins.
Facing the Fish of Fear has left this man a tragic, broken figure, but one with a prodigious taste for leeks.
The judicious lash, Sir, corrects neglect of duty, and consequently saves many a ship and fleet.
I'll have discipline and bravery at all times, or the ingrate whelps will have the lash!
Rum: a fair ration. Sodomy: never, Sir, and damn your eyes. And the lash: Pah! I am positively liberal with the lash!
Being good with numbers increases the efficiency of fleet administration, keeping upkeep to a minimum.
This man has the clarity of thought to manage both his costs and navigational calculations to a greater degree than most.
This officer's actions are reported on with approval, possibly because he writes his own despatches.
This admiral is written about with admiration by hacks, pamphleteers and other low fellows.
Newspaper editions are considered incomplete if they do not include praise of this officer.
This man has a real talent for using a ship of the line to the full.
This man is an expert in the handling of ships of the line.
This man is truly at home in those majestic castles of the sea, battle ships!
This admiral shows much consideration - too much - for the feelings of the lower decks.
A kind heart is a worthy thing, in a maiden aunt or chaplain. Finding it on the quarterdeck is another matter.
This man's public distaste for correct, if harsh, discipline is now prejudicial to the navy.
This fellow does not drink, and doesn't think anyone else should either.
Refusing to accept the intrinsic relationship between sailors and their grog, he scowls at any who call for the bottle.
He brings everyone down with his dour and joyless manner, leaving little respite from the rigours of naval life.
Honour is this man's watchword, almost his catechism.
For this man, to be a Spaniard is to be honourable, no matter what the cost. If that is death, then so be it.
This man's heart swells with pride when he thinks of his precious homeland. He is nothing without the honour of service to the land.
This man has spirit, bravado - a touch of "derring-do". Bravely leading the men in boarding actions, he isn't afraid to get his hands dirty.
This man has a talent for listening to local gossip, and for spotting those who are not local.
This man can smell out a stranger in his area, particularly one with designs against his nation.
This man has many friends, and is quite willing to listen to their opinions of foreigners and strangers.
This man's suspicious nature is backed by a prodigious memory for information, useful abilities for anyone who hunts spies.
This man has notes on everyone in the area, and is not above threatening people with exposure of their little "weaknesses".
This man has a talent for listening to local gossip, picking out of the nuggets of golden truth in the process.
This man knows many people, and listens to their concerns - and whatever else they let slip.
This man has assiduously made friends in the bureaucracy, and knows how to listen to their woes - and secrets.
This man has made a point of setting a good table, and of listening to his important guests as they gossip.
This man has made a point of being kind to servants. After all, they know all the secrets of their masters...
This man has spun a web of deception about himself and, like any spider, knows when there is a fly, or a secret, nearby.
Convention and morality do not trouble this man, except when it comes to spelling them.
Me? Help a milkmaid carry her jugs? With my reputation?
This man delights in meretricious company, relishing even the loss of reputation.
To ease his filthy ways, this man has ordered his tailor to alter - most unpleasantly, let it be noted - his breeches.
No foul act is beyond this man's pleasurable contemplation and practice. His servants walk in fear.
This man's conduct is so base and depraved that no gentleman would want to comprehend his foulness.
Why fight fairly when advantage can be gained by cunning and stealth?
A thief unhanged? A common brigand? Or a military man with a talent for the unexpected?
Stratagems and trickery are legitimate parts of the soldier's craft, and this man excels in their use.
The banditry of ungentlemanly ambushes is not to this man's taste.
This general  will not have any soldiers indulging in ungentlemanly sneaking about. And quite right too!
Underhand conduct and treacherous tricks - such as ambushes - are decidedly not in this general's mental armoury.
This gentleman does not like fighting in the backwoods of the unwashed and uncivilized colonies.
This general has developed something of a blind spot where woods, trees and Americans are concerned.
This general has learned to make use of the rugged terrain of North America.
This man has a superior grasp of the brutal business of fighting in the American hinterland.
Attacking and starting a battle are not this general's greatest strengths.
This general shows a distinct lack of talent when leading an attack.
Attacking an enemy army is one art that this man has never mastered - and the troops know it.
This man has a deserved reputation for being skilled when ordering an attack.
This man's aggressive ways are translated into tactical excellence!
This man is an extremely aggressive and skilful attacker, and with good reason.
Few generals reach such a pinnacle of expertise, and can organise and lead attacks with the facility shown by this man.
This general is a master of the attack; his opponents are crushed by his skilled management of fire and movement.
A childhood listening to his elders and betters has given this man a solid understanding of Ottoman villainy.
This man took in hatred for the heathen Turks along with his mother's milk.
This man learned the art of hating Turks at his father's knee. His has honed his skills since then.
This man thinks he understands the business of war. He does not.
Command of men in battle is a missing aspect of this man's character.
This man should not give orders to parlour maids, let alone soldiers!
This man is truly dangerous on the field of battle mostly, it must be said, to his own men!
Few men reach such depths of military incompetence and live to tell the tale.
What's a few casualties between friends? This man believes that in order to get results you have to get stuck in.
The win is the thing, does it really matter if a few degenerate ingrates get sacrificed along the way?
The day hasn't gone well unless there's blood. Everywhere. Preferably the enemy's of course, but he's not picky.
Warfare is this man's calling. His heart thrills at the trumpet's note!
This man has a splendid aptitude for war, as his enemies will discover!
This man was born not with a silver spoon in his mouth, but a sabre in his fist!
I say, those chaps over there mean to kill us! What absolute rotters! Shall we have at them?
An inspiration by example to his men, this general rightly has a reputation for bravery.
I'm sure I have better things to do with my time in battle than worry about shot and balls!
The reek of gunpowder, the clash of steel, the drum's tattoo: battle brings a knowing smile to this man's face!
Foreigners and ladies grow pale in this man's presence, but for very different reasons.
A lack of physical courage is not necessarily a handicap to high command. No, really.
This general is scorned by his own officers, and even the other ranks smile when he - all too predictably - breaks wind before battle.
This general's own trumpeting gives notice to the enemy of his fears, and all without troubling a bugler.
Courage has become a stranger to this man. His people know it, and his lack of resolution fills them with contempt.
This man has the ability to win, even when he has not chosen battle as a course of action.
This man shows a distinct talent for winning when the enemy apparently have the initiative.
This man is an expert at letting the enemy come forward to their own doom!
No attacker marches against this general with a light heart. His defensive skills are almost without equal.
Even the great captains of the classical world would be challenged when attacking an army lead by this man.
This man is unsure and slightly hesitant in defensive battles, and he rarely shows true quality.
When attacked, this man has a tendency to procrastinate, which does little to improve his performance as a general.
When this man is defending, he shows few of the qualities expected of a war leader.
I find, sir, that a little gin is very calming on the nerves and steadies a man's hand.
I am drunk, Sir, and mark me well: I intend to horsewhip your tiny green servants.
Claret. This man likes claret. Quite a lot of claret. All the claret. Everyone's claret. He has a strong bladder.
Far gone in drink, this man rarely rises from the dinner table in order to relieve himself.
This man is a natural horseman, and fearless to boot.
This man is the epitome of a dashing cavalry officer: madly brave, yet slightly less intelligent than his horse.
This general has panache aplenty. His men would follow him to the Gates of Hell!
This man has a basic understanding of the arts of war.
This man has a good grasp of grand strategy and tactics.
This man is properly counted among the great captains in battle.
Men willingly march into Hell on this man's orders, sure that he will give them victory!
Great men stand - and ladies swoon - when this singular personification of military excellence enters a room!
This man has not come to terms with India or with war in India.
The spicy food. The heat. The natives. The monsoon. The damn elephants! It's all quite, quite off-putting, don't you know!
This man shows a natural aptitude for warfare in the Indian style on Indian battlefields.
This man has fully grasped the subtleties of fighting in India, of making the best of the terrain, the climate - and the native warriors!
This man is held up for mockery in the press, even when he does things right!
This man is mocked, mercilessly and ceaselessly, in pamphlets and newspapers.
This man now twitches whenever the word "newspaper" is used within earshot.
Keep back, sir! Keep back! I will have none of your low-cut boots near me!
There's always time for a jig. Or is that a pig? A wig? No. Figs: must keep your bowels open.
Terribly noisy: your marching. What say we hop into battle this time, and whistle like teapots?
A bellicose newt with a cutlass probably has more grasp of amphibious warfare than this man.
This man would possibly do better to drown himself rather than conduct attacks from the sea.
Perhaps this man harbours a morbid dread of fish and kelp; he certainly finds crossing a beach beyond his ken.
This man has begun to master the tricky art of attacking from the sea.
This man has a distinct aptitude for amphibious warfare, and is well able to lead his men ashore against an enemy.
This man is a true sea-going warriorl, able to organise and execute attacks that take death and destruction to any enemy shore!
Drill! Drill! Drill! Constant drill is the way to win battles and move men, Sir!
The hatred of his men is something that this general relishes. It does not matter, as long as they march well!
While the men heartily dislike this man, his methods do make a hideous military sense.
Terrified by drunken Europeans as a child, this man has turned his fear into anger and hatred.
This man entertains no doubts that his righteous fury against all things European is entirely proper.
This man is the sword and shield of his people, protecting them from any rapacious and foul European menace.
This man will give nothing to the enemies of Poland save, perhaps, hot lead and cold steel.
There is iron to this man's soul, as harsh and unyielding as a Polish winter.
Every blade of grass is treated as though growing in the precious soil of Poland!
This man's every military act is reported on with approval!
The "free press" hardly ever print bad news or unkind comments about this general.
Editors fill their newspapers with laudatory commentaries upon this gentleman's many virtues.
It is fear, mein Herr, fear, that drives men forwards in battle, not the love of their officers!
The men are scum, villains and thieves all, but we shall make them into an army to fear!
This officer is so fierce that the Devil himself would appoint him Captain of Hell's Legions!
This man is burdened by his love for his motherland, for he cannot do enough to be worthy as a Russian.
This man is determined to defend the motherland for all enemies, no matter what the cost.
This man has long been a stranger to fear - and sobriety - but, by Mother Russia, he can fight!
Having a feel for terrain is a distinct advantage whilst planning when and where to fight.
Access to local knowledge and accurate mapmaking give this fellow an edge when deciding the particulars of battle.
The shallower mysteries of siege warfare have so far eluded this man's understanding.
A purblind fool is probably a better choice as a commander during a siege than this general.
This man would make an excellent faggot to fill a moat or ditch or, perhaps, he could serve as a gabion.
This general has a good, if elementary, understanding of siege warfare.
This general has an expert's intuitive grasp of siege warfare and its intricacies.
This general has an ability to breach defences usually seen as impregnable. He is a master of siege warfare.
This general has an exceptional aptitude for siege warfare, and is expected to carry any siege to a successful conclusion.
Good, solid fortifications are not a useful feature of a battlefield for this man.
This man is stunningly inept where fortifications are concerned.
For this man, walls are merely useful structures on which to grow roses.
This man understands the basics of fighting from prepared defences. Any attacker will learn this the hard way!
This man is fully able to make the best of any defensive works to hold on at whatever cost.
Give this man ramparts, counter-scarps and ravelins to defend, and he will hold until Death claims him!
This man can make a heap of rubble defensible, and could hold a wall against the Devil himself!
This General shows much consideration - possibly too much - to the lower ranks.
This man has little taste for the harsh realities of army discipline, and winks an eye at most offences.
Discipline in this man's command is a disgrace to the entire army in the opinion of his officers.
This man is blessed with a fighting spirit, worthy of his pagan Viking forefathers.
Some would call this man mad, driven to distraction by the long winter nights of his home. But the truth is simple: he enjoys battle.
Battle makes this man's blood sing. Only with the smell of blood in his nostrils does he feel truly alive or awake.
This man has a natural aptitude for the business of gunnery.
This general has, from his first days of service, shown a good grasp of artillery tactics.
This general has a remarkable understanding of the purposes of artillery, and its correct employment.
A childhood spent running wild in the woods has given this man a gift for fieldcraft.
A rebellious nature and regular beatings from Father have made this man a natural fighter.
Some claim that this man has native cunning and some native ancestry; the second is never said to his face.
This man inspires confidence in his followers by his example and his war skills.
Victory has brought this man authority, and his warriors respect, love and fear him in equal measure.
In battle nothing seems to harm this man. Enemies fall before him, and every plan seems to work without fail.
The Spirits truly watch over this man, and whisper the secrets of victory to him when he dreams.
Here is a man who knows when to shoot his load!
Gunnery is more than an interest for this man. The crash of cannons lifts his very soul!
This general is a master of using the right tools for victory: guns, guns, guns and more guns.
This general has a love of the charge - and the sense not to use his cavalry indiscriminately!
This general has all the dash and fire one would expect of a gallant cavalryman!
This general is an expert horseman, a fine leader of men and a masterful cavalry tactician.
This general has a natural aptitude for infantry combat and tactics.
This general has a splendid understanding of how to use infantry to the very best effect.
This man is seen as a harsh taskmaster and is not loved - despite his habit of victory.
'"No, Sir, I cannot cure your piles! I can, however, adequately describe them in Latin!"
The work of a lifetime should result in a tenured appointment, and access to the college's wine cellar!
Only a fool subscribes to false modesty! Sir: I am a genius!
Scientific Truth, Sir, is whatever I and the rest of the academy decide, regardless of God's intention!
A trembling hand might diminish accuracy and be misconstrued as fear. This man, however, stands motionless.
Sir! You're going to regret making sport with my new hat - by God!
A marksman of prodigious talent, his reputation discourages all but the most serious challengers.
He has proved himself adept with a duelling sword on more than one occasion.
Experienced at throwing down gauntlets, this man fearlessly plays the game of death.
An inveterate duellist, "He'll die as he lived in a flash of the blade, in a corner forgotten by no one!"
A passionate adherent of his faith, his religious principles sometimes conflict with life in the modern world.
A gentleman never interferes with his livestock, although he does study them closely.
A gentleman has time to read, think and study, freed as he is from the drudgery of the shit heap.
Generally, sir, clever landowners find a book more use than mattock when seeking profit!
Have you read my monograph upon the crossbreeding of sheep, Sir? If not, pray hold your insolent tongue!
Money is remarkable stuff - the lack of what else can stop an army? - and worthy of study.
Loans, debts, bonds and accounts make a fascinating study - for the right kind of mind.
This man's writings are probably understood by a handful of others - which makes him an influential thinker indeed!
Decades bent over the accounts may seem a waste - until the financial alchemy of turning paper into gold is discovered!
Where there's muck, there's brass - aye, and knowledge too for a practical man.
There may be trouble at t'mill but, for the right man, there's much to be learned as well.
To start with nothing, and build anything: that teaches a man much.
A lifetime spent amidst the grime of industry gives a certain solidity to a man's opinions and expertise.
This scholar is definitely more ink- than blood-stained, yet can hold forth sensibly on military affairs.
This man's scholarly works have attracted the favourable opinion of many generals; his thinking advances the art of war.
This man has made a deep study of classical  wars, and applied his learning to contemporary strategy.
This man's works are used as text books by aspiring officers in many lands - even among his nation's enemies!
A love of the sea has informed this man's scholarship, making him an authority on naval matters.
A love of the sea has informed this man's scholarship, making him an authority on naval matters.
This man's writings are required reading in many naval schools, and even foreigners read his books!
This man's grasp of all things nautical is deep and profound; his writings are influential and respected.
This man has read until his eyes have grown dim - and his mind exceptionally sharp.
A disputatious nature and access to a large library can do much for a man's mind.
To some, a lifetime of gazing at clouds seems wasteful, but answers are found in surprising places!
Even this man's eructations are a profound discourse upon the meaning of life.
This man funds his own experiments, studying for the love of learning as much as the end result.
Well-respected amongst the scientific community, he attends monthly dinners to discuss new theories with his peers.
He is driven by a need to discover the workings of the world, and to unravel the mysteries of creation.
The King's favour is a splendid thing, and an encouragement to great future efforts.
The title does help when dealing with the lower orders, it's true.
The perquisites of high position give a man a large stake in his nation's continued success.
This man has been of constant and successful service to his monarch and his nation.
It is almost impossible to imagine how this man could have brought extra honour to his nation.
This minor stomach infection will surely be gone by morning. Or possibly the afternoon.
There are good grounds for believing that this is cholera, not "something he ate."
This unfortunate has caught breakbone fever, and will feel terrible for some time.
In other men, this might be called cowardice; in this man, it is called pitiable.
This man has a sickness called "influenza" by Italian doctors, and cannot work.
This man is marked by his injured extremities.
This man is crippled by his disease, and is feared by many.
This man can barely lift his head, let alone a pen or a weapon to carry out his appointed tasks.
This poor fellow is regularly laid low by bouts of ague.
This man is covered in small, red pustules. Is it a rash, or something far worse?
It's the end of the world, the end of the world, you're suffering from life withdrawal!
This man is showing all the symptoms of scurvy, from bad breath to aching limbs.
This man has dreadful pustules over his entire body.
The smallpox has done its terrible work on this poor fellow.
This poor chap can never quite throw off a cold, as he has a weak chest.
Coughing up blood is never a good sign, as any doctor will confirm.
This man has typhus, and is unable to carry out any of his normal duties.
This man is bedridden, and his servants fear for his life.
This man's fever comes and goes, but his pains remain constant.
This poor fellow is very ill: puking blood the colour of midnight is never really a good sign.
There are spies everywhere, you know! Everywhere!
I do not trust that doorman. Or that one. Or that maid. Or you.
As a child he was awoken with the sound of cannons, followed by rigorous drill before breakfast.
This man is happiest dressed in full ceremonial garb, medals glittering at his breast.
Insisting all his attendents and ministers salute and stand to attention is possibly taking things too far.
This man's ready wits show up lesser men as dullards.
This man has an exceptional intellect, and can be applied to almost any matter.
True cleverness sometimes involves not correcting everyone else's mistakes.
A little smut may be considered witty, but not to an ambassador's wife!
This man's behaviour is boorish and nationally embarrassing, even if the ambassador's wife did have a fantastic arse!
This man's appalling behaviour would shame any bawd or panderer, let alone a lady of quality... with few scruples.
My John Thomas is a disaster area!
This man benefits from an amusing lack of intellect.
Difficult ideas are difficult, you know. One has to make allowances.
There are small bedding plants with a greater understanding of life than this man.
An advocate of rationality, reason, toleration, and freedom of ideas - although not at the expense of authority.
Proof, if ever any was needed, that it is not what you know, but who, that matters when it comes to personal success.
Blessings upon the royal household! An heir has been born, and the line continues!
An heir and a spare! Surely the succession is now safe, and the future of the royal line assured?
The royal family have been blessed with so many children, their continuance is guaranteed.
This man delights in the new, the unusual and the different.
This man shows a marked preference for foreigners, much to the annoyance of his countrymen.
Having redecorated his private chambers seventeen times in various foreign styles, this man cannot get enough of the unusual!
There are only two ways: my way, and the way to the gibbet at the crossroads. Am I making myself understood?
Right of rebellion? Traitors don't have rights, but they do make attractive drapes when hanging from the fortifications.
'Neath the velvet glove lies an iron hand. There has been occasion to bring it down upon the ungrateful populace.
This man understands religion, but it does not have a hold over him.
This man is openly irreligious, to the intense irritation of some, and the joy of others.
This man looks beyond the tradition teachings of religion for solutions to mankind's problems.
Born in the saddle, and with a hunter's keen eye, this man merely follows his natural inclinations.
A healthy interest in bloodsports makes this man popular with his wealthier landowners.
Is there anything else worth doing in life? Exactly. Of course not.
This man is not the sharpest tool in the drawer, and his twitching is a tad disheartening to say the least.
Hereditary weaknesses have revealed themselves, due entirely to ancestors being far, far too close as a family.
Wall-eyed cousins should not be allowed to marry, except amongst royalty, and then only rarely.
Children have so far been unforthcoming, despite the best efforts of his spouse.
The royal couple have not been blessed with heirs that lived.
Providence has not seen fit to bless the royal couple with offspring. Perhaps it is God's will?
An "unusual" child, his natural strangeness has only increased with age.
What, What! Tiddly-pom! A lovely day for oysters, Mother...
The monarch is clearly unwell. The slightest excitement can turn him into a dribbling wreck.
Intellectual debate is encouraged, and the educational welfare of the people is high on the list of priorities.
Correspondence flows freely between the ruler and his learned friends, such is his hunger for knowledge.
Intelligentsia have been gathered, so their knowledge and insight are at hand whenever the mood catches.
There is much worth in the practice of reading the letters of other men.
Spies and agents of influence in foreign parts help the delberations of government.
A spy sent into the world is merely a true patriot who labours without public honour.
Military promotions are based on aptitude and ability for the job in hand. Personal connections are of little value.
It is good to know other men's secrets.
There is something glamorous and dangerous about the shadow world.
A man can know many secrets, if he has the right servants in the right shadows.
Along with the poise and manner of royalty, the monarch is blessed with many princely virtues.
I am your Prince, appointed by God. I am accountable to Him and only Him.
He has contempt for the tyranny of kings, and how their whims and fancies bring misery to the lives of their subjects.
That people should live in thrall and ignorance in this age of enlightenment is the real treachery.
In childhood he could only sleep if his bedtime stories were tales of dashing maritime adventure.
He has taken to wearing ceremonial uniforms at all times, which makes bathing a difficult business.
Government business is conducted from the deck of his ship, such is this man's dedication to nautical matters.
A disdain for educational matters could be due to a love of outdoor pursuits, or just an intellectual limitation.
Books and learning are a waste of time - time that could be better spent riding, hunting, and feasting.
His refusal to invest in the education of his people keeps them ignorant and powerless against control.
Nose picking - not always his own nose, mind - is the least of this great man's unpleasant foibles.
Nothing is more amusing to this man than a good fart, preferrably in the direction of an ambassador.
This man's habit of scratching his privy parts and arse between dinner courses causes unease in visiting dignitaries.
Never short of a witty turn of phrase, this man's pithy repartee is renowned throughout the civilised world.
Despite a biting wit, he has the talent of making those concerned feel strangely better about themselves.
Unable to afford a commission, his ambitions are satisfied by ensuring the army have the lion's share of resources.
Having studied war on an amateur basis, he now favours their needs at the expense of domestic matters.
His devotion to the interests of the army borders on infatuation. Perhaps it's the fabulous uniforms?
There's nothing wrong with feathering one's own nest, surely it's merely a perk of the job?
One for me, one for thee, one for the pot. This man believes in "creative" accounting in its purest sense.
Assets have been misappropriated, but he insists the funds were only "resting" in his account.
The good things in life are there to be enjoyed, and take the population's mind off their everyday miseries.
Centralised banking reduces dependence on private money-lenders, and gives government a float to play with.
This man has faith that prudently applied, the new theories of economy will fill his nation's coffers.
He is well-versed in the new fiscal thinking, this man is consulted in all matters of national income.
Whereas most people can be appeased with cheap whores and gin by the bucket, some of us have more refined tastes.
Sir, this time you have surpassed yourself! Will you pass more of those scrumptious caramelised stoat intestines?
This man believes centralising industry and increasing production capacity are the keys to advancement.
He believes that the way forward is the centralised use of the latest machinery and production techniques.
This fellow has developed the latest industrial technology, and improved regional infrastructures to support it.
He keeps a tight rein on the privy purse strings, all expenditure must be justified in writing. In triplicate.
A career in politics was mapped out for him, but his true passion was the sea. He champions the navy's cause at every juncture.
He argues deftly in favour of developing the navy, feeling it is an essential element of national prestige.
This man's constant promotion of the navy and its wants has caused consternation amongst his peers. Hello sailor!
This man is a firm believer that agriculture is the basis of happiness amongst the people.
This fellow believes that the nation's wealth is best derived from working the land.
His radicalism borders on the republican, such is his desire to shake up the old order and improve ordinary people's lives.
This man wishes to preserve the power of the landed aristocracy, and their stranglehold over property and the people.
Realising the potential of his country's goods and resources is the road to wealth and prosperity for all.
This fellow believes in the power of a free market to maximise the nation's trade potential.
He believes the punishment should fit the crime, and be an example to other would-be wrongdoers.
Two wrongs do make a right, especially when the weight of law is behind them.
An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth. This man believes in clarity when it comes to laying down the law.
This man believes in truth and honesty, something he pursues through his work.
A respectable man of moral excellence, he does his duty with dilligence and precision.
He has great professional and personal integrity, and cannot be tempted or bribed.
After spending time amongst the native tribes, their barbaric customs have replaced his decent, civilised ways.
This man has found America to be extremely testing.
This man now uses "American" as a swear word, in place of any impious oath.
Preaching to the ignorant is always unpleasant. And have you seen those people eat?
This man would quite cheerfully consign Europe to Hell-fire.
The heat. The flies. The ignorant superstitious folk. Why would anyone want to preach here?
Even the size of India is part of a conspiracy to sap the spirit of any man.
Even the size of India is part of a conspiracy to sap the spirit of any man.
There is a rustic charm in all things in America, even in preaching God's lessons.
A simple people, and a simple message of redemption: what could be finer?
Planting the seeds of faith in fertile soil is good for the preacher, too.
There is an unalloyed pleasure in giving the faith to a people.
There is much in India to confirm a man in his faith, and make him want to spread the word.
Even the light of the Indian sun is a blessing, and lifts the spirit of any preacher.
People travel for days to hear him preach, such power have his words to move and inspire the souls of many.
The early morning runs and freezing baths of his schooldays have made him resistant to illness.
This fellow enhances his natural good humour with healthy appetites and regular exercise.
This man only feels at home when outside with the elements, away from flthy, crowded city life.
This man is careful who he associates with, trusting only a few, and telling them nothing that may compromise him.
He knows who his friends are, who the friends of his friends are, and who those friends of his friends are friends with.
He is constantly surrounded by a dozen bodyguards, all armed to the teeth and ready to spring into action should anyone even look at him in a suspicious manner.
A deeply religious man, he observes practices rites with solemn dignity.
Despite the worldly circles in which he moves, he still has deep spiritual beliefs.
The slightest thing sends this man to his sickbed - a noxious smell, bright lights, anyone from Franconia, the number six...
Perhaps an excess of bile has increased his melancholy? More likely his despondent moods have made him ill.
With death all around him, this man reckons he has all the symptoms.
The politics of power dictate his orders - he carries them out with efficiency, and a slightly worrying zeal.
He kills for the pleasure, thinly disguised as political expediency, and may be unable to stop if the work dries up.
If you kill a man, you're a murderer; kill many, you're a conqueror; kill them all...
With a cutting wit for the ladies and a cutting sword for the men, this scoundrel is a "gentleman" in name alone.
This man has a talent for provocative insults, and the skills to defend his so-called honour.
This man lives for the pain he can cause others - pain at sword's point, for preference.
He has infiltrated enemy spy networks and alerted the authorities to their presence.
Having convinced the enemy he is working for them, this fellow has fed disinformation ever since.
They think he is working for them. In truth, he's not sure who he's working for anymore.
He has successfully planted explosives during a siege, allowing his own forces to gain entry more easily.
The go-to man for all things explosive, he has successfully placed petards on several occasions.
Although dressing as a woman is a cunning disguise to aid him in his espionage work, he quite likes it really.
By day he is an ordinary fellow, by night "she" is a deadly femme fatale - after all, who would suspect a lady?
His "gentleman's club" is inaccurately named, their chief business being Bacchanalian mischief and moral impiety.
Drinking, wenching, feasting, and blasphemy are the vices of this debauched villain and his godless friends.
Their excessive drinking, mock-religious ceremonies, and blatant whoring are deplorable displays of moral deviance. Nevermind.
He has had success damaging enemy buildings, displaying an aptitude for sabotage.
You were only supposed to blow the doors off! This man is a skilled saboteur, in fact he is almost too good.
He creeps about unnoticed, pressing his ears to doors in the hope of learning useful facts.
Accepted by his quarry as one of them, this man has gained access to classified information of much use to his employers.
A highly-skilled operative, this fellow is able to pass every useful detail of the enemy's plans to his true masters at home.
A little fat on a man's bones is an attractive feature for the ladies.
Gluttony is what lesser people call a healthy appetite! They are envious, Sir, of my capacities!
A skilled combatant with both the knife and the fork. No dish is safe within arm's reach!
A meal is not properly over until this man cannot heave his fat arse off a dining chair.
His eating - and the endless thunderings from his bowels - keep this man apart from polite society.
Sordid over-eating has reduced this man to a sick, overstuffed, blubbery creature, crippled by pain.
A spade, Sir, is as good as a bayonet when applied with a little thought!
Only a gardener, a madman or a siege expert would order quite so many trenches to be dug.
Any fortress, properly invested, will fall in time. Time and good sapping are great allies!

The plagues and sicknesses of America hold no threat for these men.
This unit has been exposed to the disease and filth of Europe.
The terrible plagues of India are unlikely to harm these men.
This unit is unlikely to fall sick in the harsh conditions of the Middle East.
These men have learned the value of surprise, concealment, ambush and all-round sneakiness!
This unit has taken all that the tribes can offer and made those skills its own.
View halloo! Is there anything more stirring than the charge?
The thunder of hooves! The majesty of a charge! These men live for little else - save glory!
Fighting is a nasty business, so it pays to be better than the next man.
Killing men takes practice, and practice makes perfect.
This unit has learned that European ways may be odd, but they are effective.
These men have adopted much that is European, at least where fighting is concerned.
These men are becoming "old hands" in India and at Indian warfare.
Few men joke about this unit's quaint native ways; they look on in awe when it fights!
These men have been laid low by continuous, explosive and repulsive diarrhea.
The sick are racked by headaches and aching muscles, making their duties absolute torture.
The men of this unit have become adept at digging new latrines.
These men are racked by fevers and illness, and cannot be expected to soldier on.
These men are suffering from swamp fever, or ague. It makes their existence a living hell.
These men are suffering from the "little plague": small comfort to the sufferers in the ranks.

Sickly and barely able to do their duties, these men undoubtedly have scurvy.
The few healthy men in this unit await the appearance of their own smallpox pustules.
The men of this unit are subject to terrible coughing fits.
Typhus has laid these men low. They cannot function as soldiers.
The sick men of this unit are jaundiced, and struck down by attacks of vomiting black blood.
These warriors are protected by powerful magics, amulets, and signs. They cannot be harmed in battle.
These men are experts at moving heavy cannon across country.
These men can take an artillery piece to places that even a mountain goat would find difficult!
These men have a bloody and deserved reputation for breaking heads and restoring order.
Law and order are watchwords to these men, except where their own conduct is concerned.
These men have a remarkable record of accurate shooting.
These men can shoot a mouse in the eye at a hundred paces - or so they claim!
This crew is rather skilled in taking enemy ships.
This crew has a collective talent for mayhem, especially when boarding an enemy.
An enemy boarding party can be sure of a hot welcome from this crew.
This crew has an arrangement with sharks: they defeat any boarders, and the fish clean up the mess.

Sir, the good of the Empire and your own people have been well served by your efforts here today.
Your good sense in accepting the Empire's terms is testament to your nation's wisdom.
To cast aside Imperial friendship is a courageous act, sir - one that may be done and then bitterly rued on sober reflection.
If that is what you wish. The Imperial army will shortly arrange for your collective demise.
Your people are as untrustworthy as Magyars, sir, but I suppose we must try to deal honestly with you.
Imperial boundaries have never been set in stone. It is now time to recognise that the Empire's greatness requires certain lands from you.
Imperial servants such as I, sir, do not need to listen to your endless peregrinations. Good day.
No, no, a thousand times no! Are you a Magyar thief to think that the Empire would accept your demands?
The Empire, sir, does not allow foreigners to tramp across its lands like so many beggars and vagabonds.
As an Imperial servant I have better things to do than unpick your almost-witless sophistry, sir.
Imperial honour demands that we declare war! Imperial glory will shortly be won at your expense! Good day, sir.
Our talks here today will advance both our nations, sir, and bring wealth to their people.
You are wise indeed, sir. The Austrian Republic and I bow to you.
To cast aside the Republic of Austriaâ€™s friendship is a courageous act, sir.
If that is what you wish. The Austrian Republic counter-marches already, sir!
Our boundaries have never been set in stone. Recognise that the greater Austrian Republic requires new lands - your lands, sir.
Servants of the Republic, sir, have no need to listen to your endless, meaningless hooting. Good day.
Never! Remove yourself from my sight! I will not have the Republic held accountable for my actions, else!
Magyars! You, and yours, sir! I choke back honest republican bile at the sight of you. So, speak.
Are your men cattle, sir? Do you seek to drive them across our Republic to new pastures? In short: you will not!
Sir: inform me when you have gathered your thoughts, and have something of solidity to consider.
In the name of honour we declare war! And in the name of our glorious Republic we will break you, sir.
Well, that all went very well, sir - and now my claret awaits!
Very well, if you want it so. It will be a most frightful bore having to kill all your fellows.
HELLO! HELLO! DO. VOUS. SPEAKEN. DE. ENGLISHER? Bloody foreigners. LOOK. WE. ARE. TRYING. TO. BE. NICE. SO. SAY. YES. TO. US. OR. ELSE.
As I would say to any poacher or other verminous scum: Get off my land, sir!
Sir, I feel that I must withdraw and seek better conversation elsewhere, perhaps with some passing night soil men.
You, sir, have the manner of a frenchified fop! Your terms are ridiculous, and the cut of your breeches likewise!
In the name of their Britannic Majesties, pray remember that your words here today carry little weight.
Britons, sir, do not willingly bend the knee to foreigners, tyrants or no. We do not hold with foreigners, sir.
Your true colours as a rapacious villain are revealed at last! Great Britain, sir, is not some wench that you can ravish at will! No, sir, no!
Sir! Do you think us a nation of mollies to be bought so easily?
Sir, this is not the day that the British monarchy buys the false security you offer.
Your speech, sir, is a load of cockâ€¦ and bull. Patience has its limits!
Sir, I find it is a considerable satisfaction to tell you that we are at war. Do you wish to surrender now, or will you be tiresome?
Most noteworthy and praiseworthy indeed! Your good health, sir!
So it is war then, is it? Tally-ho, and to the field!
I must point out that foreigners do terrible things to my digestion. So, speak - quickly now - before I am forced to retire and seek easement.
British soil is for Britons, sir. It is not some bridleway for warmongering scoundrels!
Give me strength! Treating with you is as productive as the philosophy of a Bedlam lunatic!
I have struggled to understand your babblings for long enough, sir. I shall run mad if I listen longer!
Still your babble, sir, and let us converse as honest gentleman (if a foreigner can be thought such) in English.
Surrender, sir, is not a word in our lexicon. The Republic will never bow to blasted foreigners!
Not for all gold-stuffed purses of all the whores and mollies in Paris, sir!
Peace? Peace, sir? Peace! A piss upon your peace! Bring me wine!
A pox on your foreign gold, sir!
You are as mad as a Bedlam inmate, sir! We will not waste good money on your kind!
You twitter like a caged bird, sir, and with almost as much meaning!
It is no small pleasure to declare war between our peoples, sir! Will you surrender to the forces of the Republic now, or be a bore?

My noble sovereign will be delighted that our talks have ended with such a success. Good day to you, sir!
Our talks are complete and - well, a success. If you will excuse me, I feel a powerful urge to wash.
A satisfactory end to our talks, I feel. Good day to you, sir.
Do not presume that this agreement has dampened down the fires of our dislike for your nation, sir! Good day!
And so our business today is concluded in a spirit of amity. Good day to you, sir.
Your decision, good sir, is a sensible one. Agreement will bring great benefits to all.
Sir, your feckless choice in breaking this alliance will wound our people, and their trust in you. Good day to you, sir!
Our troops will march where they please, sir. Anyway, the mud of your country was ill-suited to gentlemanly pursuits.
Trade with you, sir, was largely profitless anyway, if only because your goods were so shoddy and ill-made.
Your good sense, sir, in agreeing to our counter-terms is most commendable!
My dread sovereign will be saddened that you have failed to see the value of our generosity.
My gracious sovereign will be hearitly disappointed to hear of your rejection. Let us hope, good sir, that you do not live to rue it.
Your most generous gift will surely touch my monarch's heart, as will your friendship.
Sir, I shall anticipate your utter ruin with keen - nay! - eager expectation. Good day to you!
Our beneficent monarch suggests that you consider the following proposals, and hopes that you will find them agreeable.
Our noble monarch is being generous, given your notorious perfidy. Listen well, and agree to what is proposed - if you have any sense at all.
Both our nations could benefit from this meeting, if you agree to what is proposed here today. So, let us begin.
It would be wise to listen carefully to our proposal, if you wish to improve your standing in the eyes of our glorious monarch.
Our gracious monarch extends the hand of friendship, and hopes that we may spend a little time discussing matters of mutual interest.
Everything created by the hand of man has its alloted time. I am instructed to inform you that our alliance is now ended.
Sir, our ruling house no longer sees the necessity of allowing foreign troops to tramp across our green and pleasant land.
While trade enriches, sir, we find that trade with you is an unnecessary luxury. Our agreement is cancelled.
I fear that the terms could be better, good sir, but I can agree to your offer.
My noble sovereign will not be surprised that I must reject your offer as unsuitable.
Good manners, Sir, generally embrace the concept that a nation should remove its rough soldiery from the territory of a neighbour - and immediately!
I am instructed to demand that your armies stand aside and let our monarch's glorious  forces have access to your lands for such purposes as he may consider prudent.
My gracious sovereign is sure that you will see the wisdom of parting with some of your territories to ensure our continued good opinion and support.
My sovereign requests and requires regular and continuing tribute from you. Gold is acceptable.
My sovereign expects that you will shortly enrich our national treasury; in short, we want money.
Sir, while your nation's achievements in the arts mechanical and practical are noteworthy, are you equally sensible to the need for sharing with your friends?
With respect, I feel it would now be prudent to withdraw from these negotiations.
And so we are done for today. It is a pity that agreement proved so elusive!
There is nothing more to say, sir. Our conversation has been as tedious as it was worthless.
Hardly a satisfactory end to our talks, I feel. Good day to you, sir.
With the greatest possible respect, I see that I am late for my, my - my tailor. These talks are at an end.
My noble sovereign will be saddened that our talks have not born fruit. Good day, sir.
I have been instructed by my monarch to discuss a proposal for our mutual gain.
It is regretable that my government would find these terms unacceptable.
Sir, these proposals have little to commend them and therefore must be rejected.
Rarely has our glorious nation been so insulted! We reject your offer without hesitation.
Sir: diplomatic niceties are all that are saving you from a horse-whipping! Your proposals are rejected utterly!
Our two peoples are great indeed! But standing united, how much greater would we be, Sir? How much greater?
We draw your attention to the fact that this war is bringing neither success nor profit to either of our nations. Let us have peace!
Let us discuss matters of trade and "business". I apologise, for such vulgarities should not trouble proper gentlemen.
My sovereign, sensible to the diplomatic and military realities, wishes to offer you control of certain of his territories.
We feel it would be prudent to offer you reasonable sums of money now, and in the future.
I am instructed to offer you money at this time, knowing that gold is dear to your hearts.
Sir, I am instructed to offer you access to our nation's knowledge and skills, so that your unfortunate ignorance may be alleviated somewhat.
Friends of our people and sovereign are always welcome. Now, let us discuss matters of import!
Our dread sovereign has little time to consider your mewlings, so let us be brief: speak!
Our gracious sovereign instructs me to listen to your proposals with patience and good attention.
Our noble sovereign will hear of your unworthy petition! Speak, that your proposal can be considered.
Valued friends of our gracious sovereign are always welcome. What matters do you wish to discuss this fine day?
You are a fine humourist, Sir, but quite foolish. Our armies march where they will, and we pay no mind to your mewlings on the matter.
Good manners, sir, are all that keep me from adequately expressing our deep contempt for this appalling suggestion.
Sir, we have no wish to see our land blighted by having your poxed swine march across it. Access is denied to your creatures!
Our nation may be on its knees, but we will not bow to your tyranny. Your demands are mad, sir, mad!
We refuse! Not so much as a single stone will be handed over to you, sir, unless it be a headstone!
Sir, your whores may need their trinkets, but the money will not be from our treasury!
Sir, what profit is there in paying thieves to stay away? They still have your money. We reject your demands!
Your request is insulting, sir. We do not share what our greatest minds have struggled to obtain with those too stupid to open a book.
We utterly reject your scheme! An alliance with the beasts of the field would be more congenial!
No. No. A thousand times no. The only time we will cease firing is when the gun barrels are too fouled to continue.
Sir, we are not to be bought and sold in this fashion. Gentlemen of our nation, Sir, do not "trade"!
Sir, we do not want your cast-offs, your discarded nothings. Keep your lands.
Keep your money, sir, to pay for your doctors, that they may bleed you a little and cure your weakness of the brain.
Sir, we will not take your money. It has a taint about it that turns strong stomachs!
With all respect, Sir, your wishes have been weighed in the balance against military necessity and found to be entirely wanting.
Our nation, sir, may be weak, but that frailty does not extend to our pride. Our people bow the knee to no man willingly!
No, sir, No! No infantry boot, cavalry shoe or artillery wheel shall besmirch our lands!
I had not realised that your people had a sense of humour, Sir. Your demand is rejected, now and forever!
It is an offence to my sovereign's dignity to give up one tussock - one leaf - one rock of our lands! Your request is rejected.
Sir, one demand is unreasonable! To ask for repeated payments is beyond all reason! We refuse.
Your demand, sir, is unreasonable, and your purses will go unfilled from our treasury!
Knowledge given, sir, is not as prized as knowledge won. Regretfully, we will not be sharing our learning with you.
Alliances, like marriages, are often cause for regret when the wedding breakfast is over. We must decline your generous offer.
A ceasefire you say? Is your position that uncertain? We say, no, then!
I cannot agree that our two nations need to trade, sir, for trade implies some kind of equality of worth.
I am empowered to reject your most generous offer of territory as being inappropriate to my sovereign's dignity.
We are not whores to be cheaply bought. Your money is most unwelcome, sir!
Your money, sir, is unwelcome. My sovereign's friendship is not some cheap bauble to be bought in a market!
My government has decided to make a gift to your nation, sir, showing the high esteem in which your people are universally held.
With respect, your indecision as to what you want is unbecoming, burdensome and annoying. Good day.
I am instructed to say that we are now at war. I trust, sir, you will understand if I do not wish you well.
Most satisfactory, good day to you, sir.
Our talks are complete and have achieved nought! You will excuse me: I feel a powerful urge to wash.
So our talks have come to an end, and in your favour. Isnâ€™t that wonderful?
Presumption, sir, is a trait of the foolish. Do not presume that our acceptance changes much.
Oh glorious day! Your decision will bring great joy and prosperity to our peoples.
You are wise indeed, good sir. Agreement will bring great benefits to all.
Your actions leave the Republic no choice. We must break all ties with you, and so farewell.
The troops of the Republic march where they please. Your petty concerns matter not a jot or tittle!
We weary of your slap-dash merchandise. Our trade is done.
I bow to your superior reasoning, sir.
Do not turn our generosity aside so carelessly, sir.
Our government is deeply disappointed by your decision. Let us all hope you do not live to rue this day.
You are most generous, sir. This gift is received in a spirit of friendship.
I wait with bated breath for your impending doom. Your end will bring me nothing but joy.
I pray you: consider our proposal and find it agreeable.
I will be brief. I expect nought but lies from you, sir. So, speak - the truth would have novelty!
Both our nations could benefit from this meeting. So: let us begin.
It would be wise to listen carefully to our proposal, if you wish to stay our displeasure.
In the name of the Republic, I extend the hand of friendship and hope that we may discuss matters of mutual interest.
The bonds between our people are broken, sir.
No longer will the boots of your rampaging hordes sully the good earth of my homeland.
Trade between our people may once have had its uses, but no longer, sir, no longer.
Although it will be greeted with displeasure, I must accept your offer at this time.
Do you jest, sir? Surely you must?
Do you mind, sir? Remove yourselves, forthwith!
I am instructed to demand that your men stand aside and let the glorious forces of the Republic march across your lands.
Sir, perhaps you would consider ensuring our continued good opinion by gifting the Republic with some of your lesser territories?
Perhaps we could come to some agreement. A show of your good faith would be prudent. And what is more prudent that gold?
If you wish to remain in the favour of the people perhaps a gift to them and ourselves would raise your profile?
Our nation boasts the most illustrious minds of the age, yet nature reveals her secrets to others - others who might share their knowledge?
I take my leave, sir. I no longer see worth in these discussions.
If only the allusive mistress of agreement had been more forthcoming, perhaps another day.
You, sir, are a scoundrel rogue and cad! Our conversation has been worthless!
Our talks could have ended more amicably, but it matters not.
I must away, sir, I have other pressing and more worthwhile business at hand.
It is a sad day indeed, sir. If only our talks had been more fruitful.
I am here on behalf of my government, to discuss a proposal of mutual gain.
Unfortunately, sir, this offer is unacceptable at this time.
I see no benefit for the people of the Republic here, you may wish to reconsider your proposal.
Never, in all my â€¦ there are no words to describe this insult, sir.
You, sir, will rue this day!
Power, sir, is a wondrous thing. When two nations stand as one who can say what power they may wield!
Peace sir! I say again, peace! When a war is no longer profitable to either party why, pray, continue?
Trade is the backbone of any strong Republic, let us discuss these matters now.
We recognise your nationâ€™s great power and offer a gift of land, thus showing our continuing respect.
Wisdom suggests that now is the time to open the Republicâ€™s treasury for you.
Knowing your penchant for gold, we offer it in a gesture of friendship between two great nations.
The great philosophers and sages of the Republic are available to you, sir, pray, ask of them what you will!
A pleasure to see you, sir. Now, let us discuss the wellbeing of your land and my Republic!
Our patience for you grows thin - very thin, sir! Speak briefly so I may remove myself from your odious presence!
I am to hear your proposals with patience and no little attention.
You slither, sir. Speak, that your proposal may be considered in the light of your true worth.
A good friend has value beyond any accounting. What, then, shall our conversation encompass?
Gripe all you like, sir, it matters not! The armies of the Republic march forward where we, not you, determine.
If I were a lesser man, sir, ruled by base passions, I would rend your head from your shoulders!
If your swine march across our lands then they will be penned, in a manner befitting beasts.
Even now we will not become a puppet in your interest! Away with you, you cad!
Are the free people of our Republic to meekly handed to foreign tyranny? No, sir, we will stand united!
Your leaders may seek to fill their purses by robbery, sir, but they should look elsewhere to further their ambitions as footpads!
If you were a gentleman, sir, I would consider your words, but as you are clearly no more than a brigand: good day!
Our knowledge, is exactly that, sir - ours! Why would we share with those unable to grasp the simplest of theorems!?
How could you possibly be considered proper and honourable allies of the Republic, sir? How?
When our final soldier gasps his last on a swordâ€™s point, then, perhaps, we may consider this odious proposition!
To put it bluntly, sir: no, a thousand times no. These matters are beneath the gentlemen of our Republic.
You can keep your wastelands, sir. Our Republic does not need your dungheaps!
Do you believe we can be bought, sir? Do you think us the common whores of your land?
There is a distinct stench upon your currency, sir! I fear it may offend the noses of proper gentlemen!
With respect, sir, your concerns, valid and eloquently delivered as they may be, will be ignored. Good day!
Unlike the willow, sir, we will not bend according to your windy demands!
I am flabbergasted, sir! We will have no part in your relentless warmongering!
Live beneath the heel of a tyrant, sir? Your tyranny, sir? I think not!
It is an offence to the dignity of our people to even consider this ludicrous proposal!
Sir, one demand is unreasonable! Anything further is rank lunacy!
How dare you!? The purse strings of the Republic are tied tight against you, sir!
Our intellectuals have laboured long to advance the Republicâ€™s knowledge. Their achievements are not baubles to be traded away.
The principles of the Republic prevent a union with creatures such as you.
Are you so unsure of your strength, sir? Away with you then, there shall be no respite for you!
In order to trade, sir, you must first have something to offer.
I am empowered to reject your most generous offer of territory.
Your money may be good enough for the whores of your homeland, sir, but not for us! No, indeed!
Our government and people can not be bought with your dirty money, sir.
My government has decided to make a gift to your nation. Let this illustrate the esteem in which your people bask!
The confused manner with which you make this offer troubles me, sir. I must withdraw until the confusion of brain that troubles you is gone.
I am instructed to inform you that our nations are now at war. I trust you will understand if I take my leave, sir. Good day.
Monsieur, diplomacy with you has been as pleasurable as talking with a fellow Frenchman!
Monsieur, this is a pity. French soldiers always find burying the enemy dead quite wearisome.
Ah, monsieur, this is a delicate matter. We expect you to pay us a regular tribute. Cruder minds might say that this buys you peace.
Monsieur, I have grown weary listening to your perfidious rubbish. Only an English fool would remain here any longer.
Monsieur, your proposals have wasted valuable time that I could have spent with a charming young ladyâ€¦
Monsieur, no Frenchman of honour who respects his monarch, could possibly agree to such nonsense!
Let us open a bottle, monsieur - not the muck we send to England - and consider matters that touch on our mutual benefit!
Sir, French savants are geniuses and - at the command of the highest in our land - do not share their work with lesser, foreign minds!
Are we Englishmen to be bought in such a fashion? No, monsieur, we are French, with French honour and French sensibilities.
No, monsieur. No true Frenchman would let our precious land be crushed beneath the boots of your army.
No, monsieur, we Frenchmen are not Englishmen to waste our lives haggling like common grocers.
The French royal court is not a den of moral harlotry, monsieur. Not at those prices!
Are you of French descent, monsieur? You conduct yourself with the dignity of a true Frenchman!
Such a pity that the soldiers of our Republic will get dirty uniforms when they vanquish your men.
The people of our glorious Republic expect a few simple trinkets now and then, sir.
Monsieur, I weary of your inane posturing. I sincerely hope that it is a lifetime before our paths cross again.
Do you think my time worthless, monsieur? Surely you do, to have frittered it away with these jabberings!
Monsieur, no Frenchman of honour could possibly agree to such nonsense!
Let us raise a glass of French wine to the prosperity of our peoples - and all they may achieve together!
Frenchmen are the greatest thinkers in Europe, monsieur. That - correctly - implies that they do not think thoughts for lesser people.
Am I dressed like a harlot, monsieur? Do I cavort like one? No, sir, no! Do not presume to treat me so!
Our land is far too beautiful to wither under the heavy and ridiculous boots of your army!
I care little for your turnips, or what ever it is you deem valuable in your pigsties!
The French are not harlots to be bought at your whim, monsieur. Never at those prices!
I wish you joy of the day. Our business is done and other matters of weight must requrie your attention.
I would as soon kiss a thousand snakes as treat with you, but this treaty was required. My - undying gratitude.
And so an agreement is reached. We are content in that.
There are evils that are necessary, like this agreement is an evil. Our rajah does not willingly deal with low creatures such as you.
And so our business here is concluded most successfully, and with good fellowship. This is good karma!
All men will bless your good sense in this matter!
Your are not a nation, but a nest of cobras: dangerous, unpredictable and full of venom!
Our warriors' ways are not to be dictated by you, but your objections are noted and will be remembered.
Very well. Your merchants were uncouth, unwashed vagabonds anyway, and we will be glad of an end to the unpleasant odour.
Your acceptance shows wisdom. It is good that this marketplace haggling can be ended.
Your rejection of generous terms wounds me deeply; it will wound my noble rajah equally.
Disappointment is the natural condition of man. You have added to my burden of disappointment.
A gift sincerely given is a blessing to the giver, as well as the recipients.
Your bones will become one with the dust. Your blood will be washed away by the monsoon rains. War it is.
Greetings. I come in friendship, so that we may profit by talking of great matters.
Greetings from my noble rajah. You are utterly unworthy to hear his words and it is my profound misfortune to deliver them.
I am here to talk. Karma will determine the outcome.
My rajah would send his greetings, unworthy one, if he set any value at present on your friendship.
Greetings from my lord. He sends good wishes for your prosperity and fertility. It is time to talk of matters of great import!
In the affairs of our two nations, the time has come for a parting of the ways. All things pass.
Sometimes it is not wise to invite armed men into your house. Sometimes it is wise to ask them to leave.
Our trade agreement is over. Your goods were inferior, your gold adulterated and your merchants were in want of a good wash.
Your suggestions are good, and there is much wisdom in our agreement here today.
I must reject your most generous offer. It would wound my noble ruler's honour too deeply to accept.
Perhaps you imagine that my Lord is too busy debauching himself to notice the armies that trespass on his lands? Remove them, now!
My prince feels that his armies should not be... restricted in where they can march: across your lands, for example, would be useful.
It seems reasonable to us that you should grant my prince authority over some of your extensive lands. You will hardly miss them!
My prince expects that you will be willing to contribute to his treasury from time to time.
My prince reasonably expects a contribution to his treasury from you. No reasonable man would refuse!
It seems that your scholars show unexpected wisdom! Would it not be equally wise to share the fruit of their labours with my lord?
This day has grown wearisome. It is time to seek refreshment, and other company.
Our lack of agreement here should not be seen as failure, but as a chance for friendship to bloom in future.
There is not water enough in all the Ganges to wash away the stain of treating with such as you!
And so agreement is not reached. Perhaps it was never meant to be. Such is karma.
You have all the wisdom of the eastern end of an elephant watching the sunset. We are done here.
We have talked, as good friends do, and agreed to differ. Our karma is enhanced.
My lord requires that we talk about matters of mutual - convenience and profit.
We are not children or low-caste vagabonds, who will agree to any proposal.
The sun of India has not addled our brains! We will never agree to such terms!
Your proposals are foolish. Are unschooled monkeys running your country?
Even the lowiest leper in all of India would never agree to your terms!
When tigers prowl, wise men seek friends. Let us, then, be allies against the world!
