It is time to haggle like common merchants, I fear. Trade is a necessary evil, although the high born should rarely trouble themselves with it.
My prince has been reviewing his domain; it has become plain that some of his lands would be better off with different masters.
My rajah knows that government sometimes requires distasteful acts, and so is willing to offer you reasonable payments.
Although the consequences cannot be foreseen, my lord feels it prudent to offer you a modest financial gift at this time.
Our scholars have much knowledge that my lord imagines you might find of interest. Perhaps this measure of wisdom would be of interest?
Greetings, friend. Your words are always welcome, being those of a friend.
There are tigers with empty bellies who are eager to meet you. I do not share their hunger for your person - or your gabble!
And so you have come - with some small dignity, I see - to treat with us. Speak then, and be an honest man.
I am here to listen to your ignorant gabblings, but I do not expect any point or profit from the experience.
Be welcome, in the name of my noble rajah! Let us talk, mutually profit by it, and renew our friendship!
No! My Lord's armies will march where he commands, not where whining baboons such as you instruct.
May you have no profit from this turn of events. A thousand snakes nest in your bosom, and hatch out to consume your dark heart!
Why would we let your uniformed lepers march across our lands? Are we moonstruck madmen?
We do not yet lie in the dust! Your demands are outrageous, and are rejected in the name of Indian courage!
We refuse. Not one handful of earth - not one cupful of water - no tree - no flower - nothing - will be given to you.
No. Our gold will not be sullied by any touch of your hands.
A most amusing joke! Once a thug is paid, he remains a thug. He does not forget his strangler's ways. We will not pay.
You must think our wits were washed away in the monsoon rains! No, we will not share our knowledge with idle creatures such as you.
I would sooner see us allied to gibbering rock apes than to men of your kind!
We will sheathe the sword when your guts are spilled in the dust, and not before!
We do not want your trade. When we require dung, we will look to our elephants!
We do not need your lands, full as they are of low caste beggars, diseased wretches, liars and the children of liars.
To insult a prince is one thing; to repeatedly insult him shows little grasp of reality. Naturally, your offer is rejected.
Your money has a taint to it, and my lord does not care for its lustre. Your offer is rejected.

A thousand years of weeping would not be enough to wash away the shame if we agreed to such an outrage.
We must decline your request. Your soldiers would frighten my lord's servants unnecessarily, and cause congestion upon his highways.
Regretfully, my lord must decline your kind offer. He does not need your assistance or protection for his people.
My lord's lands were not idly acquired, so they are not to be given away in a similar spirit.
No, we will not act as your tax collectors, squeezing the people of their wealth simply for your benefit.
No. You cannot simply invite yourself into my lord's treasury on a mere whim. Do you think us such great fools?
A fine joke, but our scholars do not work for your benefit. No, we will not give you knowledge that you are not ready to receive.
An alliance you say? No. I doubt we travel the same road.
When one has released a tiger, the tiger decides when it is time to stop biting. There will be no ceasefire.
Thank you for such a kind offer, but no: our craftsmen and merchants feel your goods would not find a market in our lands.
While my lord would rule your people well, his tax collectors would not be welcome there. He cannot take these lands into his domain.
We cannot accept your money. My lord's would suffer a loss of face no wealth could mitigate.
My lord cannot accept your money. While the gesture is appreciated, it is not one that is truly sincere.
Please accept this small token of my rajah's admiration for your nation. It is a trifling thing, but sincerely offered.
Is your unfortunate weakness of brain the result of being frightened as a child by a baboon?
War has come! The sword is unsheathed! It must be blooded before it can be put down!
Our meeting is done. Our thanks, and the blessings of the Republic, go with you.
The needs of the Republic are all, and so we agree this treaty. I would rather have seen you fed to a tiger, in truth.
Our day has been well spent! The agreement here will benefit the Republic!
I have grown weary of your yapping, but the treaty makes even that worthwhile.
Our friendship has brought a worthy treaty. Let it continue so!
Your good sense will be a blessing on all our peoples!
Is this how you treat friends? We are then honoured to be counted among your enemies!
Our armies march as they will, not subject to your lowly opinions.
At last! Excellent! Your merchants were unfathomably greedy, little better than the brigands of the hills.
At last the bartering has come to an end, and a successful one I believe.
Your rejection is that of a beggar: ignorant and proud in his ignorance.
We respect your decision, even while we regret the choice you have made.
The Republic always welcomes gifts, especially those given in sincerity.
Your hovels will be trampled in the dust, your names washed from history. It will be as if you never lived!
In the name of our glorious Republic, I approach you with an offer of friendship.
I have not come to bandy crooked words with a witless worm! Speak now, before my mood further darkens!
Karma dictates I may live to regret this meeting, but for now, I am here to talk.
Unworthy though you are, you have my ear. Do not fecklessly use my time.
Greetings! It is time to disscuss matters of great import, that can only benefit us all.
The Republic is done with you. We have kept  company with snakes and dogs for long enough.
Your soldiers are frightening our women and children - and even the cows. Remove them from our lands at once.
Our agreement is at an end, sir, the Republic has no need of your shoddy goods.
Your terms are fair and wise. The Republic is pleased to accept them.
We must reject your proposal. Surely it would injure the Republic in ways we refuse to contemplate.
Perhaps you imagine that we are too busy - in debauching ourselves, perhaps - to notice your armies? Remove them, now!
It is obvious that our armies should suffer no restrictions in their marches, even across your lands.
It seems reasonable that you should give some of your extensive lands to our illustrious Republic. You will hardly miss them!
Perhaps you could make your respect for our great Republic known to all? With a little gold, shall we say?
A reasonable request, for a reasonable payment. No man of prudence would refuse.
It seems that your scholars show unexpected wisdom! Would it not be equally wise to share the fruit of their labours?
The time has passed all too slowly. Our people do not expect their servants to waste time further in this fruitless fashion.
I look forward to our next meeting, certain that it will bring more profit than today. Farewell!
My time with you has drained me! I must retire to seek better company - perhaps with a passing leper!
These talks go nowhere. It is time to end them, before weariness makes fools of men.
Talking to you is like trying to lead a cantankerous elephant to water: pointless and painful!
My most valued friend, we have been at odds this day, but let us not allow one disagreement tarnish our friendship! Farewell!
I come before you to discuss matters for the good of the Republic.
We are not some snake you can charm as the whim takes you.
Such terms are an insult to our nation and all we hold dear!
Your people were fathered by a cobra, that much is clear! Your poisons will not work here!
You call those terms? There have been messages scrawled in the dust with more meaning and worth!
When tigers prowl, wise men seek friends. We of the Republic are wise indeed and our friendship is highly prized!
This war brings only suffering and misery, to both our peoples. It is time to set aside the blade and the gun.
Trade between peoples can lead to many places; may it take us to the lands of peace and prosperity.
It is clear that some of our people would be better off with different masters. This has been a difficult matter for our Republic.
Government sometimes requires distasteful acts, and so I am here before you, to offer payment.
Although the consequences cannot be foreseen, we feel it prudent to offer you a modest gift at this time.
Our scholars have much knowledge that may be of interest to you.
Friends of the Republic, be welcome! Your words are always a great comfort to us.
You crawl at the feet of the mighty Republic like a dog! Speak, we have little time for your people.
You have been received, but this does not mean that your requests will be accepted by our Republic.
You preen and fuss like a peacock; do you also have the brain of a bird, sir?
Welcome friend! Let us talk to our mutual profit, and thereby renew our friendship!
We are as strong as we are steadfast! We see no reason wear our soldiers by listening to the demands of overwheening monkeys like you!
Will our demise really bring you joy? If so you are truly worthy of your vile reputation as destroyers!
Your men are scurrying rodents, not soldiers! And like all rats, they are a plague - so, no!
We have strength yet to repel any creeping things that come against us, even you!
The land belongs to our people. The Republic does not go against the interests of its people, no matter what their birth.
Our gold will never fill your coffers! We are not goats, staked out for the tiger to eat!
We would sooner cast our gold into a cesspit than see it in your hands. Look to it there, but never from us!
Knowledge is not for the ignorant and foolish. Why would we ever raise you from the dust of failure?
Wise men do not trust snakes, especially deadly ones.
Our swords are hungry! Are we to deny them further blood? I think not!
You have nothing that the Republic would value, not even your plain and unwashed women!
Your lands are plagued by your foolish people -  they are of no use to civilised men such as us!
Your money is worthless to us. The Republic will not be bought like a goat!
Even a beggar of the lowest caste would not take your money! He would sooner his begging bowl was empty!
Our armies march where they must. The concerns of lesser nations do not weigh heavily in the balance.
The rivers have run red with the blood of our people, and now you expect the living to bow down in the dust! The answer is no.
We must refuse your request. Your soldiers would cause congestion upon the highways.
The protection of the Republic has always been our chief concern, but we refuse your offer.
Our lands were paid for by toil and blood. They are not to be given away to satisfy your whim!
Our people have money for themselves, not for thieves and brigands!
No. You cannot simply invite yourselves into our treasury. Do you think us fools?
Our scholars, like myself, are men of dignity, and will not have their labours picked over by vultures.
Our Republic walks another road for now, and without the company of many.
The Republic sees no reason to cease hostilities against your people - no, not a one.
Your offer is generous, but we must decline. I am certain our people would not welcome your goods.
The lands of the Republic are quite sufficient, although our thanks to you for this offer.
We cannot accept your money. Surely your pride should be worth more than your treasury?
Whilst your gesture is appreciated we doubt its sincerity.
Please accept this trifling gift, as a token of the Republicâ€™s admiration, with my sincere compliments.
Have your brains been addled by the heat? Was your father a holy madman?
War! Doom to you! And death to all those unfortunate enough to find themselves among your people!
And so we have finished our negotiations with an agreement, as God willed it. My Lord will be pleased that our friendship is strong.
Do not think, servants of falsehood, that this agreement is more than a convenience. You were born dishonourable, and so you remain in my Lord's eyes.
And so we are done. My Lord will, I suppose, be pleased with this successful outcome.
Think, unworthy ones, on your unworthiness - and on how my Lord's virtue is so great that he uses you with kindness in making this agreement.
My Lord will be well pleased that an agreement has been struck with you, his valued friend.
So, long, hard haggling is a forgotten art among your people! Still, my Lord offers a good bargain.
Faithless servant of Iblis! Your friendship was like the desert wind - full of grit.
Your decision to bar your lands to my Lord's armies is, of course, yours to make. Short-sighted and ill-advised, but yours nonethless. We will not forget.
Very well, we did not like your trade goods anyway. Now that we have chance to think on it they were, for the most part, unfit for the faithful to possess.
A little haggling in the marketplace is a good thing, and brings a good bargain for all. My Lord will be pleased.
God grant me strength! Truly, you are more trouble than a herd of startled goats.
My Lord will not be pleased to hear of his offer being cast aside.
My Lord will be most pleased by your tribute, and the recognition of his greatness that it entails will gladden his heart!
We do not fear your guns and swords. But when the will of Allah, the All-Mighty, prevails - then you shall truly fear us!
It is good that we meet and talk as friends. My Lord wishes to express his admiration for you, and his hopes for a successful outcome.
Faithless ones! Bow down in abject terror and listen to the words of my Lord!
Greetings! My Lord has sent his unworthy servant in the hope - not the expectation - that these talks will be successful.
My Lord commands me to speak to you on matters of import. For myself, I would sooner talk to my camels.
Let us talk as friends and, God willing, reach an agreement that is pleasing to my Lord! Now, to beginâ€¦
Sometimes the will of God is not as all men would wish. The time has come for our alliance to end.
Your men may no longer march across our lands. The smell disturbs our camels and horses.
Trade between our peoples must now, regretfully, cease. My Lord has decided that your goods befoul his lands and his people.
Let us be done with haggling like goatherds. Your offer is acceptable at this time.
My Lord will shower his praises upon me for rejecting your proposal as unworthy.
Your armies seem untroubled by the ability to understand maps! Remove them from our lands right now!
Our armies, being both mighty and swift, would benefit if they could march across your lands. This benefit, I am instructed to seek here.
My Lord is willing to ease your burdens by taking control of some of your lands. God willing, you will see the wisdom in what we suggest.
Ever the soul of reason, my Lord feels that his good will towards you would be guaranteed if you were to make many payments into his coffers.
My Lord feels that his friendship would be well served, perhaps guaranteed, if you were to make a contribution to his wealth.
While your educated men are no better than the donkeys of my Lord's domains, he feels that their discovery would be properly exploited under his guidance.
The sun sinks. It is time for the faithful to be about matters of import rather than this jabbering.
And so our talk must end without agreement. But be assured, friends, that my Lord will bear you no ill-will.
Begone, worthless servants of a worthless people! This talk was a sham, a waste - chattering to donkeys would have been more profitable!
We are finished. Would that these talks had been useful to my Lord's causeâ€¦
We are finished and nothing worthwhile has been said. God willing, it will be a lifetime before we meet again.
And so we must end these talks without agreement. But, friends of my Lord, this does not alter the love he bears for you.
God willing, we can reach agreement on this proposal.
No, we are not simple desert fools who will agree to any scheme, no matter how far-fetched or mad.
No. We are not the wives of desert goatherds, who can be bought with a handful of shiny trinkets.
You are brave to make such a suggestion. In another place, you would feel the scimitar's edge for less!
Your proposal befouls the very air we breathe, dark servant of Iblis!
A wise man, under the guidance of God, seeks friends everywhere. And so my Lord offers you friendship and an alliance.
Let us consider a peace treaty! Allah, the Merciful, loves those who seek the ways of peace!
Trade is the lifeblood of our people! We love it more than the sword! Let us trade together then, and have much profit by it!
I am instructed to offer you, as a token of our support and admiration, new lands for your burgeoning empire. God willing, you will rule them well!
I have been instructed, worthy ones, to offer you a subsidy to aid you in your efforts. God willing, you will accept.
God willing, you will accept this token of respect: a small gift from my Lord's coffers.
Our scholars are the envy of the world, subtle and deep in their thoughts! My Lord feels that you may appreciate the knowledge that he offers.
Welcome! God willing, our friendship will blossom as a result of this meeting.
So you have come to spill out more of your lies upon an honest man's ears? Speak, but do not expect us to listen with respect.
Greetings. Courtesy demands that you are made welcome, but nothing more.
Be welcome, strangers. So, let us talk then. But understand: my Lord would dislike you and yours if he ever bothered to think of you.
Welcome! Let us take coffee together, and discuss the business of our Lords and masters in a civilized fashion.
God willing, you will not be struck down for insolence! We are not a herd of camels to come and go at your bidding! Our armies march to our designs, not yours!
Shaitan fathered thee upon a scorpion! Even now, in his moment of weakness, My Lord will not bow his head to such as you!
No! Do we invite brigands into our houses and let them make free with our wives and daughters? Are we touched by the sun? Again: no!
By the beard of the Prophet - peace be upon him - you are insolent, infidel dogs. Your demand is madness, and we reject it.
Faithless child of a scorpion! A thousand curses upon you for asking such a thing. Not one precious stone will ever be given willingly!
No! Once the goat thief is paid, he returns for a camel, a rug or two, or a wife! Our money stays in our treasury.
Your demand is refused. I would sooner kiss a camel's backside than carry your ridiculous request back to my Lord!
That your scholars have as much wit as a particularly stupid goat is no problem of ours. Continue to wallow in ignorance!
An alliance? With sons of dogs such as you? Allah be merciful, and do not strike this camel-faced fool down just yet - he is too amusing!
Why would we rest before your guts are spilled upon the sand for dogs and scorpions to gnaw upon? Beg all you like, but war is the path we tread!
We do not want trade. Our merchants claim that your goods would be most offensive to the eyes of the faithful, and I do not doubt them.
O! A thousand thanks for this excellent proposal! My Lord has no wish to take your lands. They have been fouled by your presence and wicked, faithless ways.
No. We are not kept women to be cheaply bought and used at your whim and pleasure, unlike your own mothers and sisters, I believe.
Infidel money is unwelcome among the faithful. Take it away.
While your request is reasonable, these are not reasonable times. Our armies march where they must, and do not wander at whim.
No. We will not bow to your demand! God willing, we will rise again, and once more my Lord will have strength in his sword arm to match his iron will!
Truly, you live in the abode of war. My Lord, who dwells in the house of submission, sees no reason to let your men walk in his lands.
And so that is your proposal? My Lord acts as an underling to no man! Your suggestion is absurd, as any rational man would recognise.
You jest, and most amusingly too! My Lord will not hand over even the meanest of his possessions to your tender mercy.
No, we will not give you money, now or in future. I do not even need to broach the subject with my Lord - I know that he is fond of his gold.
No, we will not pay. I regret that my Lord would be unconvinced by the scant wisdom in your request for money.
Addressing the profound ignorance of your scholars is hardly a matter that need concern us. Your request is refused.
An alliance you say? My Lord has plenty of friends and servants to protect his interests, and sees no need to add to that tally.
An end to the fighting? Have you grown so afraid for your lives? Well you might - God favours only the faithful!
We will not trade with you. Is money the only thing that you worship in your dishonourable nation?
Our thanks, but no. My Lord has no wish to add territory to his domain thanks to a misguided attempt on your part to gain favour.
Do not insult us. My Lord is not some mercenary or petty functionary who can be had as a servant - and for a mere servant's wages!
My Lord is not one of your lewd serving wenches, whose services can be bought for a handful of coins!
My Lord desires that, God willing, you accept this token of his everlasting friendship and appreciation.
An end to this talk! Even a camel would die of boredom awaiting sense from your mouth!
Your doom is hereby pronounced! Once roused, the servants of Allah are a thousand times greater than any sword or cannon!
Agreement with valued friends is always a most pleasing thing.
Do not think, servants of falsehood, that this more than expediency. You were born dishonourable, and you will die the same.
And so we are done! God willing, the next time we will conduct ourselves with a little more cordiality.
Think, unworthy ones, on your unworthiness - and on how our Republic has redefined nobility in making this agreement.
God willing, this agreement will mark the start of many more profitable exchanges! Peace, and prosperity, to you!
Good, a bargain offered and accepted is a welcome end in itself. You have shown wisdom.
So be it, sons of Iblis! We now see your friendship for the Republic was base and vile!
God willing, you will see that your request was imprudent and lacking in true friendship. Were your roads really too busy for our army to pass?
Our people will weep at the thought that they will no longer receive your fine trade goods.
A little haggling in the marketplace is a good thing! God willing, this agreement will please all parties.
You would surely try the patience of the Prophet, peace be upon him!
To cast aside proposals made in the name of our Republic is an insult.
Your tribute is both fitting and welcome. The Republic does not forget friends such as you.
War! Very well, war to the knife! The scorn of your people will fall on your unworthy head when their children are fatherless!
It is good that we meet as friends. We wish to express our admiration for you, and our hope for a successful outcome.
Faithless ones! Bow down in abject terror and listen to my words!
Greetings! There are ways in which our two nations may assist each other. Let us talk of these now.
I have been commanded to speak with you on matters of import. For my own part, I would sooner talk to camels.
Let us talk as friends and, God willing, reach an agreement that is pleasing! Now, let us begin.
There is a time and a season to all things. God willing, you too will see that our alliance must come to an end.
Please stop your troops marching in our lands. They disturb the camels and molest the goats.
Trade is ended. The hideous goods you have foisted upon us will no longer be allowed to cross our borders.
The Republic accepts your terms and, God willing, all will be well as a result.
I cannot agree to such a proposal. My good name would be forfeit!
How dare you unleash your dogs of war in our lands? Remove your armies, now!
The armies of the Republic are swift of foot, and you would barely notice their presence. So, may they cross your lands?
A true friend can ease your burdens by taking on the duty of rulership. God willing, you will see there is wisdom here.
Let no man say I am not the soul of reason. All I ask is that you add gold to our coffers, now and in days to come.
Our friendship would be well served - perhaps guaranteed - if you were to show some golden evidence of your good faith.
Our scholars, subtle and deep in their thoughts, seek wisdom everywhere. God willing, you will share your learning with us!
The moon has now risen! This dayâ€™s talk wearies me. We are done! The blessings of the Prophet, peace be upon him, on you.
And so we must part as friends, but without agreement. God willing, we will meet again, and with more profit of the day.
Be gone, worthless servant of a worthless people! This talk was worth less than a fart from Iblis!
Our talks are done, and without agreement. It is as God wills, then.
I pray that we do not meet again for many moons. Now that we part, tell me this: were you fathered by a camel?
And so we part but, God willing, our friendship remains firm and true. We will meet again, and in the name of friendship, reach agreement.
In the name of the Republic, let us talk of matters of great import.
God did not curse the men of our Republic with stupidity. We cannot agree to your proposal.
The Republic cannot agree to such terms. God willing, some better bargain can be struck.
Beard of the Prophet - peace be upon him - give thanks that I do not answer your insults to the Republic with a sword!
That you live is testament to my good manners, not to the wisdom of your utterances!
A wise man, under the guidance of God, seeks friends everywhere. And so: we seek an alliance.
Allah, the wise, the merciful, smiles on those who end bloodshed! Let us fight no more!
Trade! Our people are masters of this art! May their skill bring great wealth to our nations.
I present to you, in a spirit of friendship, lands in need of good government.
In respect of your worthiness, accept this tribute - and more in years to to come.
God willing, you will accept this token of respect: a small gift from our coffers.
Our scholars, subtle and deep in their thoughts, are the envy of all! God willing, you will see the benefits of their wisdom!
Salutations, I hope our friendship may blossom like the beauty of the lotus.
I believe you are here to pour poison in our ears. Speak, but remember we are rightly suspicious of your words.
I bid you welcome; expect nothing more cordial.
Be welcome, strangers. So, let us talk then. But understand: you trouble my thoughts.
Welcome! Let us take coffee together, and discuss matters of business in a civilized fashion.
The Republic sends its men where it will. We do not listen to the orders of stinking goatherds!
Surely a scorpion lay with thy mother! Your words are a sting that we will resist to the last!
Your brigands must remove themselves. Their stench and infidel ways make them doubly unwelcome.
Surely Iblis has placed a madness in your soul! The Republic will protect its own people.
Our people are not goats, to be handed over to satisfy your gluttony. The Republic will not give one grain of sand to you.
Your greed is most impressive! God willing, your guts will be stuffed with something other than our gold. You will have nothing from us!
You speak, but I hear the sound of a camel breaking wind.
No. Our sages tell me that your people are too stupid to understand even the simplest of ideas.
Our Republic does not need the friendship of the infidels and unwashed goatherds found in your nation.
Peace will come when dogs have fed upon your faithless guts, and only the winds remember your mewling cries for mercy.
Your goods annoy even the camels that carry them, let alone our merchants. We'll have none of them.
The land have been fouled by your presence and your wicked, faithless ways. The honest people of the Republic do not want it.
I am sure your mother was for sale, and at a good price, but our people are not!
Your infidel money reeks of dishonesty and lies! Not one coin of it will sully the treasury of our Republic.
Your lands lie between our armies and our enemies. We will not argue with the will of God in arranging the world so.
The Republic is in a perilous state, it is true. But, God willing, we will never bow down to you.
Truly, you live in the abode of war. We who dwell in the house of submission, see no reason to let your men walk in our lands.
The people of the Republic, God willing, will remain free! We will not dwell in your house of discontent.
God willing, the Republic will stand united for many years to come! We do not give up our lands because someone asks for them.
You ask for gold? Are you so lacking in pride that you will sell your fellowship for money?
We will not pay. The Republic has pride, and I am unconvinced your arguments.
Your scholars have nothing worthy or ingenious to offer the Republic!
An alliance you say? We choose our own friends, and they do not include your people!
Why should we put aside our swords? Are you so lacking in courage that you will not see this war to its proper end?
The Republic will not trade wil you. Gold is not the only thing that measures the worth of a man.
God willing, the Republic will grow in extent at a time of our choosing, not when you give up your wastelands.
You offer gold? In the hope of buying our good opinion, perhaps?
Our people are not like the lewd women of your land, easily bought for a few coins!
God willing, we hope you will accept this token of our Republicâ€™s everlasting appreciation.
Shall I summon my physician? Has some sickness brought on this confused babble of so many ideas?
The faithful do not shy from battle! God willing, the Republic will spill much of the blood of the faithless!
Allah, the Merciful, loves those who come to wisdom, even by the most unlikely paths!
Faithless, worthless, oath breakers! This is how trust is repaid, with duplicity!
The faithful do not fear your swords, your guns or your words! We are armoured in virtue, so let war come! We welcome it!
You are children of unbeliever dogs, and your witless proposal is refused.
The Prophet, peace be upon him, smiles on those who seek to avoid bloodshed. Let us consider a peace treaty.
You are lucky to be received at all, infidel dog. Speak quickly, and do not delay me from my prayers!
Peace to you, friend. Let us talk, and let our councils be as Allah, the Merciful, wills them.
Why would my prince allow servants of Iblis to march across his lands unhindered? Is he so much of a fool?
My prince sees no reason to be merciful. The sword was drawn and it is not time to sheathe it.
We will not take your money. It has an infidel taint to it.
Enough! Your endless bandying of words would confuse even the wisest fakir!
In the name of all that is holy, my prince will not rest until you are trampled beneath his elephants! This is war!
Even the most stubborn of oxen eventually sees the way ahead. God be praised that you have seen wisdom!
Oath breaking is a sign of weakness: a sign that a snake strangles your heart.
As God wills! The bite of a rabid dog holds more terror than your warmongering!
You worthless dog, your proposal is that of a outcast madman!
The way of peace is always worthy to those with a faithful and honest heart.
Infidel! You dare treat with our worthy Republic? Even though we listen, we know your words are poison!
May the blessings of Allah the merciful, be upon our friendship and our dealings this day.
Do you consider us fools? The servants of Iblis are not permitted to wander the Republic as they will!
Show you mercy? The sword was drawn! It is not yet time to sheathe it.
Your money is of no interest to the Mughal Republic.
Hold your tongue! Your ramblings would try the patience of a thousand men! There is no sense to your words.
By our glorious Republic, I would see you trampled by an elephant! This is war!
I believe we can agree to your proposal.
I regret that we cannot agree to such terms.
On your knees, faithless ones, on your knees! How dare you stand in the presence of the Sultan's ambassadors?
No, we servants of the Porte would rightly be flogged for agreeing to such a proposal.
In a just world, the Sultan would have you flayed alive for making such an offer!
A thousand times, no. Be grateful that you will not feel the executioner's blade for uttering such words.
So you have come to speak a thousand lies and then a thousand more. Speak, but do not expect honest Turks to listen long!
Be grateful your insolent tongue is still in your head after uttering such an outrageous demand!
So now you add cowardice to your vices of warmongering and whoring, do you? Well, our swords are not yet awash with your blood!
There will be no trade with you. But tell me, unworthy dog, does your mother still sell her - "skills" in the marketplace?
The Sultan sees no reason to let foreigners wander across his lands. You may not pass.
The offer is well meant and kindly, by your lights, but the Porte has no need of allies such as you.
No! The Sultan's armies do not cease their warmaking because you find it inconvenient. They stop when the Sultan wishes it!
The Sultan's rage knows no bounds against you, unworthy dogs! This is war! Your generals' skins will be used for our drumheads!
On your knees, faithless one, on your knees! How dare you stand in the presence of an ambassador from the Republic!
Infidel dogs! God willing, the heads of your generals will decorate the battle standards of the Republic!
Where are the pincers? Any tongue that insults the Ottoman people so should be pulled out!
In the old days of the Sultans, I would have ordered an imaginative death for you. Our Republic is gentler in its refusals.
Would that I could have you flayed, and your skin sent back to your infidel masters. Then they would appreciate the meaning of â€œNo!â€
Your cowardice is sickening. Peace? Never - no true Ottoman ever puts down the sword!
Do infidel dogs walk upon their hind legs in the market? I have learned something new this day!
May I be flayed alive if I agree to such a proposal!
Ottoman armies are not lighted turned aside by words. The war continues until you lie in the dust!
No. The Ottoman Republic does not understand why your generals advise you so badly.
An alliance implies an equivalence between the contracting parties. Do you match in any way the glory of we Ottomans? No.
Your lies will fill my head with the buzzing of a thousand insects, but speak if you must.
The Kingdom of Prussia, sir, is a nation of practical men. That is why we demand the right to march across your lands. It is a practical matter, that is all.
The Kingdom of Prussia, sir, does not give its agreement lightly - or foolishly! Therefore, no, no and again, no.
Prussian blood and Prussian sacrifice have hallowed our lands. We will not let marching armies besmirch that sacrifice.
Guns, sir, are sometimes not enough. At times, one also needs friends. We Prussians can be good friends.
The Kingdom of Prussia, sir, may have better things for its ministers to do than listen to your inanities. Nonetheless: begin!
Very well, sir. The Kingdom of Prussia has never shrunk from a fight. We will meet on the field of national honour!
Prussians do not stop firing until their foes are utterly devastated, sir. Utterly.
No, sir, no! Are there words in your native tongue for honesty and honour?
Very well. We Prussians will merely march along a longer road!
Prussian honour, sir, demands that you are told that we are now at war. Prussian arms will shortly best you!
Prussians, sir, in the service of their kingdom and defence of their homes, do not tolerate the march of alien armies across their lands.
Very well: good Prussians must march forwards along other roads to glory!
Very well, sir. No Prussian shrinks from the cannonsâ€™ roar! We will meet on the field of national honour!
We are a nation of practical men, sir. Which is why we intend to march across your lands. It is merely a small practical issue, after all.
Do you seek to anger us? If so, congratulations, sir! Your accomplishment must give you joy.
A Prussian, sir, does not give his agreement lightly - or foolishly! Therefore, no, no and again, no.
Friendships can be valuable things, sir, none more so than the friendship of an honest, honourable, republican  Prussian.
Sir, I would sooner face you with sword in hand  but, as I speak on behalf of Republican Prussia, I will hold my temper!
The Prussian Republic, sir, does not tolerate the march of lesser people across its lands.
The honour of our Republic demands that our guns will never be silent until the last of you is blown to perdition!
Prussians have fought and died to protect the Republic. It will never be dishonoured by your presence!
Damn you, sir, we have serious matters to consider! Yet I find myself here listening to your inane ramblings.
For the honour of the Republic and its people, we will crush you under foot! Good day, sir!
The wolves take you! This is a bad day, but we must agree to all that has been proposed if the honour of the Tsars of old is to be preserved.
Ivan Grozny, blessed be his memory, would have nailed your mouth shut for such insolence. Be thankful we live in more merciful times!
False friends dissemble. We Russians say what we want: our Imperial armies need to march across your territory, for the greater good of all.
The wolves take you, sir! This has been profitless! Oh - to have lived in the days of Ivan Grozny, when such as you would have been properly boiled!
Be grateful that the days of the old Tsars are long gone, else your impudence would have been punished!
In the name of the Imperial family and Mother Russia, welcome! Take bread and salt, and then we will share good counsel!
Not one stone of Mother Russia will ever be yours - as long as the Tsars rule and the people love them!
Once fed, a bear always comes back. And so the gold of the Tsars will never stuff your greedy bellies!
Mother Russia is Mother Russia. Indivisable. One country under the Tsars. Our lands are not so easily given up.
Did you really think the Royal family would sell themselves like ignorant serfs?
Silence! Do you think Russians are fools? Your words are a bear trap, a snare for the unwary.
The children of Ivan Grozny are on the march! They come for you, marching beneath the banners of the noble Tsars!
The wolves take you! A sad day - that the Republic must agree to these terms.
If I served the old Tsars, I would have you knouted for your insolence. Sadly, our Republic is too civilized sometimes.
The Russian Republic has a need to send its armies through your lands. Will you stand aside in wisdom and let us pass?
A slow and painful death be yours! May wolves choke upon your innards, sir.
Be thankful that the days of the old Tsars are long gone. Sadly, we live in more enlightened times now.
Welcome, in the name of the Republic of Russia, welcome! Take bread and salt, and then to our talk!
Not one stone of Mother Russia will ever be yours - not as long as the Republic stands strong and an honest Russian draws breath!
Your poorly-judged demand will gain your nation nought but pain and suffering!
Mother Russia is Mother Russia: one and indivisible! Our lands are never given away.
Did you really think the great Russian Republic would sell itself? You are a greater fool than we imagined!
I will not be ensnared, like some unsuspecting bear, by your deceitful words!
The mighty soldiers of the Republic are on the march! Tremble in fear! They come for you!
And so, senor, we reach a happy outcome. God's blessings upon our work today!
Very well, war it is. I will light a candle for your soul, for it must be stained for your part in this matter.
Greetings from the court of Their Most Catholic Majesties, and their worthy Ministers, to you and your noble people!
Senor, you are without honour and breeding to espouse such a foolish policy. On your head be the consequences!
Senor, the day is done and I would be at prayer. These talks are finished.
And now I must away. I fear I must face a heavy penance for having spoken to such as you - and all without success.
Honest Catholic piety, senor, has not addled our brains. We will not agree to these terms.
Their Most Catholic Majesties consider that this is the moment to reaffirm Christian principles of mercy and peace.
My conscience troubles me, to be meeting with such as you, so be swift!
Spanish gentlemen, senor, do not sully their hands with a labourer's tasks. Your "trade" is an insult to all that is noble!
Senor: natural philosophers rarely respect God's handiwork. Therefore, such an exchange would be little more than blasphemy masquerading as policy.
Senor, you are as slippery as a Moorish eel! Be still!
And so, senor, our work here is done. The needs of Republic have been adequately served by this meeting.
Senor, you are a hapless fool! The friendship of the Republic is not some trinket you can cast aside to your whores!
In the name of the Republic, sir, we declare war upon your ungracious nation. And may it profit you little!
Greetings, good senor! I pray our meeting is profitable to one and all!
Senor, this has been long and tiresome. I retire in the hope that my sanity may be still be salvaged from the rocks of your intellect.
This meeting has bought me only dishonour! And for what? Nothing, senor, nothing.
Spanish pride cannot simply be laid aside, senor. It has made us the Republic we are today!
In the name of Christian virtue, the Republic offers mercy and peace.
This meeting is not favoured by our people, senor. You should know this before we begin.
Trade? What could you possibly offer that the Republic of Spain cannot already provide to its people?
The thoughts of our people will never be an open book to you, sir!
Senor, you seem incapable of rational thought. Are you quite well?
So, our alliance is over. Breaking up is never easy, I know. There is nothing we can do?
We have done it all before and now we are back to get some more! Our thanks!
Sir: if you change your mind, I'm the first in line.
Facing twenty thousand of your friends, how can anyone be so lonely? War it is, good sir.
We have been cheated by you since I don't know when, sir, so we made up our minds, it must come to an end!
Sir: here is where the story ends, this is goodbye.
I don't want to talk about the things we've gone through, sir.
May we all have a vision now and then, sir, of a world where every neighbour is a friend. And thus: an alliance!
I am not ashamed to say, the roar of guns and cannons almost made me cry, but even so: you cannot send your troops into our lands.
We tried to hold you back but you were stronger, and now it seems our only chance is giving up the fight. But so what? We reject your demands!
Money. Money. Money. While it may be funny in a rich man's world, we will not succumb to your blandishments!
The history book on the shelf is always repeating itself. Tremble, because the children of Gustavus Adolphus march against you!
So, our alliance is over. Breaking up is never easy, I know. There is nothing we can do?
We have done it all before and now we are back to get some more! Our thanks!
Sir: if you change your mind, I'm the first in line.
Facing twenty thousand of your friends, how can anyone be so lonely? War it is, good sir.
We have been cheated by you since I don't know when, sir, so we made up our minds, it must come to an end!
Sir: here is where the story ends, this is goodbye.
I don't want to talk about the things we've gone through, sir.
May we all have a vision now and then, sir, of a world where every neighbour is a friend. And thus: an alliance!
I am not ashamed to say, the roar of guns and cannons almost made me cry, but even so: you cannot send your troops into our lands.
We tried to hold you back but you were stronger, and now it seems our only chance is giving up the fight. But so what? We reject your demands!
Money. Money. Money. While it may be funny in a rich man's world, we will not succumb to your blandishments!
The history book on the shelf is always repeating itself. Tremble, as the proud sons of Sweden march against you!
The bargain is struck. Farewell, friend, until we barter again.
Your hearts are false, but this bargain must hold. If it does not, our war chiefs will have their say!
And so we are done. We have a bargain. Let us put an end to talk.
And so we have a bargain. Do not think that we do not think you false and cowards at heart, even if we have made this agreement.
So we have a good bargain, and our friendship is stronger for it. Farewell!
It is good to talk with honest men, whose hearts have wisdom and strength.
A word once spoken has value to a warrior. Your hearts are not true, so the loss of your friendship means little.
Our warriors go where they will, and hunt where they like, but we hear your words and will stay out of our lands - for now.
So, you reject our trade goods. We did not like your goods anyway. Your filth made our lodges smell bad.
It is good to be done with bargaining! We are not arguing over a blanket or a new wife, after all.
You listen, yet you do not hear. Our words to you would have been better never spoken.
Our bartering was sincere. My heart is heavy at your refusal.
A gift? It is good that you have seen our worth, and the bravery of our warriors!
War? This is a good day to die, as your warriors will soon find out!
Let us talk together as fellow warriors. Let us speak words of truth, that we may bargain honestly.
Listen to our words, false ones. Listen, and we may yet reach a bargain!
It is time to talk. Hear the words of our tribe!
We have come to talk, although we do not expect much from the day.
It is good to talk. Truth is found in  your words and our words, spoken as they are by friends.
We have been friends, but no longer. The alliance treaty is done. We are not enemies or friends. You mean nothing to us.
Your soldiers disturb our peace, and the rest of our forefathers. You may not walk freely in our lands any more.
We do not need your trinkets or your merchants - liars and spies, all of them! Trade is ended between our peoples.
Wisdom is there for all to hear in what you have said. We agree.
No. Your bargain is sincere, but it is not what a warrior can accept.
Your soldiers have no need to be in our lands. They disturb our ancestors, so make them go! Go now!
Our war chiefs say their warriors need to cross your lands. Do not fear - they are not hunting your people! Will you agree?
The spirits of your land are not happy. Give the land to us, so that we may look after their needs with true respect.
You value gold greatly. We want to understand why, and would like you to send us some of your money from time to time.
We have seen that you value money greatly. It would be a sign of good will if some of your moneyâ€¦ became our money.
Our chiefs have seen that you understand much of the way that the world works! Please, share your wisdom with us!
Put an end to these needless words. We will speak no more.
My heart is heavy. Each failed to say what the other needed to hear. Farewell.
Your tongues and hearts are full of falsehood. There is no bargain to be made with men of your kind.
And so we are done. Let us put an end to talk, and bargain on another day.
Now hold your lying tongues until another day, when we will try to barter once again.
We go on separate paths, then, as good friends must sometimes. Farewell.
My people wish to bargain with you.
No we cannot agree. You may think us a simple people, but we are not stupid.
I cannot agree to your bargain. My people would laugh at me if I did!
In another place, you would be hanging head down over a slow fire for speaking such words!
No! I would sooner have wolves gnawing at my guts!
Our war chiefs are wise, and see that even brave men need friends when danger is near. Do you agree to an alliance between our peoples?
The women wail over their lost sons! It is time to talk of peace, and seek it as true warriors must do in the end.
Sometimes it is better that men trade rather than fight. This is a day for bartering.
These lands are yours, if you want them. Our people have not been happy living there and our ancestors have not found peace.
You value gold above almost everything else. We will add gold to your treasury for many winters to come, if that is your wish.
We have seen how much you value gold, and so offer you this for your treasury.
Our wise men have deep understanding of the world, and our chiefs wish them to share this with you.
It is good to talk with fellow warriors. There is a strength in your words that matches our own.
Speak, but do not think that your words have worth. Dogs are counted more worthy than you.
Do not think that you are welcome, but we will listen to what you say. Now, speak, for patience is soon spent.
It is good to talk with friends and great warriors such as you. Let us bargain, then, as friends.
We are not wolves or coyotes to be frightened away by your noise! Our hunters and warriors go where they want!
We may be weak, but our patience with you is long. If it were not, your tongue would be ripped out for speaking such words!
No, no, no! If you disturb the spirits of the land with your iron tread, then the curse of our people will be on your heads!
My people are weak, that is true. But the iron in the hands of our warriors are still sharp. We will not bow to dogs such as you.
A fine joke! Our warriors would smile if they could hear your fool's talk! You cannot have our land! Take it, if you can.
We will not pay women like you in gold. If you threaten us, we will pay you in lead - and sharp steel!
Ha! You ask for gold! The only thing I give you is this: the contempt of a real warrior!
Our wise men do not share their knowledge with stupid coyotes!
No! I would sooner run with a hungry wolf pack than have cowards and women like you as allies!
So! Now your coward ways are seen! Our war chiefs thank you! We do not stop a fight because you are afraid!
Barter? With you? Why? Do I want my people to be cheated?
We do not want your lands, given like a handful of cheap beads. When we want your lands, we will come and take them, like honest men!
We are not your - whores? - to be bought and kept! We are warriors, and free men! Keep your trinkets!
Even an old woman of our tribe knows better than to beg for a quiet life, like you do!
Our people will hunt where they will. Before you came these were our hunting lands, and our fathers are here.
Our people have suffered, but our hearts are still strong and true. We will not give up our last hunting grounds to you! Not now! not ever!
No. Our wise men tell us that the spirits of water, trees and rocks would be disturbed by your soldiers.
Our people may have suffered, but they will not lie in the dust at your feet! We will not give up the freedom of our lands to you!
The land, the spirits, our hunting grounds, the graves of our people - these we do not give away. No.
We will not give you gold in return for any of your promises. They are written in smoke, and disappear just as easily.
Not one bead, not one buckskin, not one pelt will be paid to you. We do not buy peace!
No! Our wise men may know many secrets - but they are secrets that you were never meant to know!
No! We do not value your friendship quite as much as that. When the time comes, our warriors fight for our people alone!
Why should we stop fighting? Our war chiefs laugh at the idea of not fighting you!
Sometimes it is good that men trade rather than fight. This is not one of those times.
We do not need new hunting grounds, and do not want lands where you have walked and disturbed the spirits.
You pay servants, do you not? We are free men, not women to be bought and ordered as you will.
Thank you, but what would we do with your money? Our lands, a river full of fish, and the soft breeze are all that we need.
We wish to honour you with a gift, one warrior nation to another.
Enough! Enough! The bargain changes with every word you speak!
Our war chiefs have seen enough! War is the only path left open to us! You will soon meet your ancestors!
Though it pains me to admit it, sir, we have a day's work here - and some good.
Homespun wisdom makes for honest dealings. It's good that you have seen the right in what we propose.
Very well, sir, declare your war upon honest American souls. Honest American guns will be our answer!
We reckon that it's worth our while talking for a spell with straight folk like you. There's matters need settling.
Tie me to a skunk if I think it's a good idea treating with varmints like you, but we need to talk - well, like honest men, if you can do that!
Sir, our larger aims require that you stand aside and allow American arms to cross your lands unmolested and unhindered, like sensible men!
Our dickering has been entirely profitless thanks to you, sir. Good day!
I'd sooner be a matron in a Boston bawdyhouse than deal with men like you, so speak your piece and let's be done!
Our nation, sir, was not founded so that we could bend the knee to bloody Tyranny! Your demands are insulting, sir!
Why do you hate freedom so? We will not send our people into bondage!
You may take us for simple folk, be we will not be bought or bullied! Your uniformed mercenaries cannot pass!
Sir, not one penny in tribute! Not one penny I say!
Good American ingenuity will not be traded away like a lame horse at the county fair. Knowledge is earned, sir, by honest toil.
American patience has limits. A simple, honest fellow such as myself is unused to your endless sophistry, sir.
Good, honest, American truth will always prevail, sir, which is why I gain some satisfaction in this declaration of war against you and yours.
We have accepted for now, but the wind can change. A favourable breeze might take us far from your company.
Your petty threats donâ€™t frighten us! Our Republic is built on the firm foundations of freedom!
If I were here on my own account you, sir, would be staring at your own guts. But let us talk for a while afore I get to my pleasure.
Americans, sir, are accustomed to going straight to a thing, not walking softly the long way around! Our armies will pass.
American honesty prompts me to observe that you, sir, are mulishly stupid, and there's an end of it.
Sir, the American people may be a young nation by the standards of some, but we still see where there is no advantage in a bargain.
Damn your eyes, I'd sooner treat with a dead beaver, so say your piece and be gone!
Do you think we will cast aside our glorious liberty? Freedom is seldom free - good and true men died for ours!
Our people have fought long and hard for the land they call home! Their freedom comes with a motherâ€™s milk, not at your whim!
We are no gaming board for the stratagems of others! Take your army and stick it - in a place that good manners keeps me from naming, sir.
Not one penny in tribute to foul tyranny, sir. The Republic pays such demands in lead and cold steel!
Our money is the product of good, honest American hard work! And it shall remain firmly in our treasury, sir.
American ingenuity, sir, will remain American!
You may think me a simpleton, sir, but I can tell when a man is stalling!
Pull down your britches and prepare for a whipping! War it is, sir!

Jakob Le Blon, a German artist and engraver of French extraction, has produced a colour mezzotint using three different colours combined. Le Blon produced a separate plate of yellow, red and blue - estimating the amount of each colour required in each part of the engraving entirely by eye. The result is a truly amazing innovation, making him a pioneer in the field of printing and colour separation.

Tea merchant and self-styled political emissary James Tilly Matthews, recently released by the French (after their efforts to ignore him failed and imprisonment seemed the only way to keep him quiet), has warned of a sinister plot to undermine the government in London. A shadowy band of "magnetic spies" - the "Air Loom Gang" - are said to have perfected the "Air Loom": a diabolical mesmerism machine able to influence and persecute individuals from a distance through the medium of animal magnetism.\\n\\nThe malign effects of the Air Loom, what Tilly refers to as "torture-at-a-distance", are evidenced by "foot-curving, lethargy-making, spark-exploding, knee-nailing, burning out, eye-screwing". The unfortunate Matthews now proclaims himself a victim of these symptoms, doubtless as a result of attempts by the pitiless gang to silence his momentous revelations.\\n\\nUndeterred, the gallant Mr Matthews recently took the matter to the House of Commons, crying "Treason!" at the Home Office minister, whom he felt to be implicated in the plot. Shortly afterwards he was removed from the House, and is currently residing in the nearby Bethlem Hospital for those not entirely connected to the real world.

George Fordyce is a doctor whose liking for a drink has bestowed upon him an unusual bedside manner.\\n\\nOnce called to the bedside of a lady whilst under the influence, he was actually too inebriated to take her pulse properly, and muttered "Drunk by Jove!" to himself - before leaving in a hurry. The following day, Fordyce, expecting to be reprimanded for his conduct, arrived completely sober and entered the ladyâ€™s room with trepidation. Imagine his surprise when his charge confirmed his diagnosis, begged his forgiveness, and gave him one hundred pounds and a promise to abstain from the bottle from then on!

Dr George Fordyce has led an unusual life. Having studied the eating patterns of lions, he became convinced that man need not eat more than a single meal each day, provided that meal was of sufficient quantity and contained plenty of meat.\\n\\nEvery day at four o'clock for the last twenty years, Fordyce has been to Dollyâ€™s Chop House in Paternoster Row and ordered: a one and a half pound rump steak, half a chicken, a plate of boned fish, a pint of ale, quarter of a pint of brandy, and a bottle of port.\\n\\nBefore setting out on his medical rounds, Fordyce would then go on to three separate coffee houses, consuming a large glass of brandy at each. Unfortunately Dr Fordyce has just died of gout, unconnected to his diet of course.

A furious storm has hit New England, continuing for over a week and stopping for no more than an hour or two.\\n\\nHeavy snow in nearby forests has driven wild animals toward settlements - in turn threatening livestock and food supply. Pastured cattle have frozen to death in snow drifts that have covered houses to their third storeys, and made barns accessible only through their hay lofts. People have even resorted to burning their furniture as they are unable to reach their wood supplies, and food has been scarce for those who rely on the local farmer to deliver it to them.

Following extensive persecution in their native lands for their practices of adult baptism and opposition to the union of church and state, the Amish have been granted safe haven in America by prominent Quaker William Penn.\\n\\nA radical sect of Mennonites from Switzerland and the Palatinate, the Amish are regularly martyred there by an intolerant opposition - oft by tying them in sacks and throwing them into rivers to drown. As their very existence is under threat, the Amish are moving to Pennsylvania en masse at the invite of William Penn - as part of his "holy experiment" in religious tolerance.

Savoyard mountaineers Dr Michel Paccard and his guide Jacques Balmat have completed a successful ascent of Mont Blanc, highest of the Alps and the most treacherous climb amongst them.\\n\\nCompleting a challenge first set out a quarter of a century before by the scientist Horace-Benedict Saussure, Paccard planned the expedition in detail for three years. Intending to gather accurate information about the true height of the peak, he studied the grand plateau of the mountain with binoculars in order to gather information on weather patterns, and the likelihood of avalanches occurring.\\n\\nAfter recruiting Balmat and following a hazardous climb of almost three days, they finally reached the summit. Once there, Paccard was unable to gather the information he wanted due to damage to his barometer. Unable to find shelter and snowblind, he was led back down to their bivouac by Balmat, returning safely to the valley the following afternoon.

The entrepreneur and natural scientist Baron Sigmund Zois has funded many scientific and cultural works in the name of enlightenment. His sponsorship of the expedition to scale Mount Triglav, the highest peak in Slovenia, is no different. Four local climbers have successfully completed the climb, a source of pride across the entire Empire.

The aberration of light - giving the stars and planets the impression of movement - has been discovered by Astronomer Royal James Bradley.\\n\\nBradley postulates that at the moment of observation, the position of any celestial body is displaced according to the finite speed of light and the velocity of the body upon which the observer stands - in this case the Earth, which can of course vary according to its orbit around the Sun.

The first fleet of convicts has arrived to form the new British penal colony in Botany Bay, New South Wales.\\n\\nEleven ships carrying around fifteen hundred people have finally arrived after a punishing journey of eleven months. Governor Arthur Phillip arrived ahead of the fleet and found that the bay did not live up to his expectations, there being little fresh water and poor soil.\\n\\nScouting further north along the coast they have found a more suitable site for habitation, naming it Port Jackson. The convicts have been set to work building their own dwellings and preparing the soil for agriculture.

The actor, theatre manager, and some-time poet Colley Cibber has become an unwitting literary trailblazer through the publication of his "autobiography" - a seemingly random collection of anecdotes and memoirs about his extraordinary life.\\n\\nAlthough the piece is rife with unreliable chronology, scant regard for the facts, and a degree of total fabrication, it remains useful as a unique record of the personalities and goings-on in the London theatres of the late seventeenth century.\\n\\nCibber, the son of an expatriate Danish sculptor, entered the theatre as a reaction against his parents' desire that he enter the clergy, and has developed a reputation for excellence in comedic roles, but is much-maligned as a tragic actor.

The noted composer Johann Sebastian Bach has presented six instrumental works to the Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt, originally under the title of "six concertos with many instruments" - soon to be more commonly known as the "Brandenburg Concertos".\\n\\nCritics have noted that the pieces contain the "widest spectrum of orchestral instruments in daring combinations", and that "every one of the six concertos sets a precedent in scoring". No doubt Bach hopes to gain patronage from the Margrave, a long-standing patron of music and the arts.

Johannes Sebastian Bach, the great composer, has died at the age of sixty-five.\\n\\nHis health had been in general decline for some time, to the extent where his employer - the Elector of Saxony - had already been searching for a replacement Kapellmeister from the burgomaster at Leipzig. Bachâ€™s eyesight in particular had become very poor, and so the British Opthalmologist John Taylor attempted an operation to correct it - sadly during which the composer died.\\n\\nMany in the press seem content to blame the surgeon for Bachâ€™s death, whereas other more reasonable reports have suggested Bach was killed by a stroke brought on by the pneumonia he was known to suffer from. He leaves a body of work containing more than one thousand pieces.

Staying in the town of Arnstadt, Thuringia, noted organ player Johann Sebastian Bach has produced something of a minor classic in his "Toccata and Fugue in D Minor".\\n\\nRecently, Bach has been in thrall to the organ master Dieterich Buxtehude, eventually walking the two hundred and fifty miles to Lubeck in order to visit him at his home! Buxtehude has been an enormous influence on Bachâ€™s style of composition, and the young composer stayed several months longer than intended in order to pick up as much as possible from the old master.

Now living in Kothen under the patronage of Prince Leopold von Anhalt-KÃ¶then, his Kapellmeister Johannes Sebastian Bach has produced a collection of pieces entitled "The Well-Tempered Clavier" - intended "for the profit and use of musical youth desirous of learning, and especially for the pastime of those already skilled in this study".\\n\\nContaining twenty-four pairs of preludes and fugues, the first pair are in the key of C Major, the second in C Minor, the third in C# Major, and so on in a chromatic pattern across the entire scale. No doubt this collection will prove to be a useful tool for the development of any music student, as the pieces can easily be transposed for stringed instruments.

The great composer Johannes Sebastian Bach has produced a second volume of his "Twenty-Four Preludes and Fugues".\\n\\nTo the educated observer, the work appears to be a natural companion piece to his earlier "The Well-Tempered Clavier", and has already been referred to as "Book Two", although the composer has not indicated as such.

Quaker engineer and mathematician Benjamin Robins has completed his experiments with ballistics and fortification, publishing the results as "New Principles in Gunnery". Included in this volume are his notes on the motion of projectiles and the airâ€™s resistance to them, the ranges of mortars and cannon, the flight of rockets, and the advantages of "rifled" gun barrels.

Benjamin Hoadly, the Bishop of Bangor, has caused a theological argument during delivery of a sermon to the monarch, quoting from John 18:36 - "My kingdom is not of this world".\\n\\nHoadly has reinforced the current royal view regarding the separation of church and state - that the Lord has not delegated authority to individuals, and the church should be concerned only with the kingdom of heaven - leaving government to the ruler and their parliament.\\n\\nImmediate counter-attacks have been made, and the Convocation has created a committee to investigate the matter further.

Founded in 1776 by lawyer Adam Weishaupt in Ingolstadt, Bavaria; the so-called "Illuminati" has been forced underground by decree of the Elector Palatine, who has banned all such "secret" societies from practicing freely in his lands.\\n\\nIt has long been the suspicion of his ministers that such societies are seeking to undermine and bring down the accepted order of government within society, something that will simply not do! The Elector is an enlightened man, and right-thinking men surely trust his ability to steer the ship of state through waters both troubled and calm.\\n\\nWhether the societyâ€™s two thousand reputed members across the continent will disband or continue to practice in secret we may never know, as with the effects of their allegedly nefarious attempts to influence world affairs.

The Belfast News Letter has been published for the first time under the sign of the peacock in Bridge Street. Known simply as "The News Letter", the paper will be distributed all over Ireland and will take the position of an advocate of union with England, as opposed to the more seditious, nationalistic view of rival publications.

Twenty eight year old pirate captain "Black Sam" Bellamy - so called as he did not wear a white powdered wig, instead growing his own black hair - has been shipwrecked on a sandbar off the coast of New England with his flagship Whydah and prize ships laden with booty. Just nine men have survived the wrecks, seven of whom have already been picked up and will stand trial for piracy.\\n\\nBellamy began his career trying to salvage some of the many shipwrecks along the Florida coastline, but soon turned to piracy when his chosen line of work proved fruitless. Joining the crew of Benjamin Hornigold, Bellamy soon proved his mettle and usurped power and command of the ship Marianne. Before long a second ship, Sultana, was taken - exchanged for the three-hundred ton slaver Whydah shortly after that.\\n\\nThroughout his short career in piracy, Bellamy became known for his kindness, mercy and generosity - both to his victims and the men who served with him - earning him the name the "Prince of Pirates".

Originally intended as a method of training for soldiers in Norway, the first winter biathlon for sport has taken place. Combining cross-country skiing and target shooting, the first competitors are different border patrol regiments. Due to the success of the event plans are afoot to extend the competition to a summer variant also.

Big Bottom, a new settlement on the Muskingum River in Ohio, has come under attack from a native war party, resulting in the brutal deaths of eleven men, one woman and two children; as well as the capture of three others. A handful of survivors were forced to flee for their lives.\\n\\nDespite the existence of a treaty between native tribes and settlers, areas in Ohio are still disputed. This has not stopped the Ohio Company of Associates from proceeding with its program of settlement there however, although the financial strain has led to under-investment. This regrettable situation may go some way towards explaining why the settlers kept such a poor watch over Big Bottom, and why they had not even completed the construction of the blockhouse.\\n\\nThe tragedy could have been much worse if not for the actions of Colonel William Stacy of Marietta, who skated thirty miles up the icy river to bring word of the impending attack to his two sons, only one of whom was to survive the massacre.

The anatomist Luigi Galvani has become the first man to investigate the presence of electricity in the muscles of animals.\\n\\nWhilst cutting a frogâ€™s leg his assistantâ€™s scalpel accidentally touched the copper hook the animal was hanging from. This resulted in a twitching of the muscles in the frogâ€™s leg. Galvani was fascinated, soon discovering that simply touching the end of the scalpel to the nerve - with the other end touching the power source - was enough to cause the same involuntary movement in the dead frog. From this he has concluded that there is a relationship between the "animal electricity" flowing through animal bodies and the movement of their muscles.

The vicious pirate Edward Teach - known to all as Blackbeard - has finally been defeated and killed in battle with the Royal Navy. Even though he had been pardoned under the recent Act of Grace, Blackbeard was still targeted as a dangerous freebooter by the Governor of Virginia - who commissioned two sloops under the command of Lieutenant Maynard to track him down.\\n\\nEventually finding Blackbeardâ€™s ship in a North Carolina inlet, Maynard attacked Teachâ€™s ship Adventure, giving chase as it attempted to cut anchor and escape. Managing to fire on Adventureâ€™s rigging and forcing it ashore, Maynard ordered his crew below so that Blackbeard would board his sloop. As predicted, he took the bait and boarded with ten men, unprepared for the attack of Maynardâ€™s men.\\n\\nDuring the fighting, Blackbeard was cornered and eventually killed by blood loss from multiple sword blows and gunshot wounds. His head was later hacked off and hung from the bow of the sloop.

The Reverend Stephen Hales of Teddington has long been respected for his detailed scientific studies of the natural world. Building on his previous work concerning the pressure of sap in plants and the transpiration of moisture from the leaves, he has now discerned a natural pressure in the blood of living creatures.\\n\\nHis method of testing is to insert a brass pipe into the artery of a horse, to which a glass tube is attached, then observing that the blood within the tube could be seen to rise - and has concluded that this must be due to pressure.\\n\\nPresently, the method of observing this phenomenon is highly invasive, so the medical benefits of this discovery may take a while to present themselves.

So named due to his background of moderate wealth through landownership, the "Gentleman Pirate" - Stede Bonnet, an associate of Blackbeard amongst others - has been captured and executed for buccaneering in the Caribbean.\\n\\nAlready pardoned by the Governor of North Carolina, and issued a letter of marque to privateer against the Spanish, Bonnet soon returned to piracy in 1718. The Governor of South Carolina tasked Colonel William Rhett with bringing Bonnet and his crew to justice. Rhett came upon Bonnetâ€™s ship whilst it was being repaired on the Cape Fear River. A furious battle ensued that lasted several hours before the massively outnumbered pirates surrendered.\\n\\nAfter being held for three weeks, Bonnet was sentenced to death on two counts of piracy following the betrayal of a crew member who turned King's Evidence against him in return for the sparing of his own life. As a last resort, Bonnet wrote to the Governor of South Carolina to ask for clemency - a move which proved fruitless as the Governor endorsed the Judgeâ€™s decision, and Bonnet was hanged without delay.

Eight men have been recruited to act as a bolster to the will of the Bow Street courts at the behest of dramatist and magistrate Henry Fielding - and paid for directly from government funds.\\n\\nIt is this official link to the courts that differentiates them from the now-common thief-takers, and also goes some way to curtailing the widespread corruption that remains rife in that profession. The Bow Street Runners do not patrol the streets, instead arresting perpetrators on the direct authority of magistrates and travelling the length and breadth of the country in order to pursue specific individuals wanted for prosecution.\\n\\nThis law enforcement innovation is the first step towards greater control over the spiralling crime rates in the capital and other major urban centres.

The natural historian and occasional doctor of medicine Sir Hans Sloane has bequeathed his large collection of curious objects to the nation, including many books, manuscripts, drawings and pressings. They are to be housed in a special museum for everyone to see, including a reading room for scholars. It has also been decreed that the museum will receive a copy of every book printed from now on.\\n\\nAfter much deliberation and the rejection of Buckingham House, the trustees have decided on Montagu House as a suitable venue, purchasing the house for twenty thousand pounds.

Described as a wolf-like creature as large as a cow, with a tuft of hair almost like a lionâ€™s mane, a long tail and a black stripe down its back; the infamous beast of Gevaudan has finally been put down! Following over two years of brutally maiming and killing the local population, and a failed attempt to kill it by professional wolf hunters, local man Jean Chastel has been credited with bringing down the beast. Supposedly it appeared before him whilst he was reading the bible, and apparently Chastel finished his prayer before slaying the creature.\\n\\nWhether this is true remains to be seen as the animalâ€™s body has not been recovered. However the killings have stopped, for the time-being at least.

Jack Broughton, first prizefighting champion of England at the heavyweight level, has defined a set of seven rules governing bare-knuckle boxing encounters at his London amphitheatre.\\n\\nThough Broughton holds no official station beyond the stature due to his title, these rules have quickly found favour with proponents of the pugilistic art. Prior to this, many such encounters were little more than chaotic free-for-alls, frequently with fatal consequences. This is not to say that Broughtonâ€™s rules wholly dispense with the raw nature of proceedings - throws and falls are still permissible, rounds last for as long as both fighters remain on their feet, the number of rounds is limited only by the protagonists ability to come up to scratch in time, and no allowance is made for injuries - however serious.\\n\\nBroughtonâ€™s rules are known as the "London Prize Ring" rules, and have set the fledgling sport on a path toward acceptability.

For over five centuries 25th March - or Lady Day - has marked the beginning of the new year. Lady Day is a celebration of the Annunciation - when it was revealed by the Angel Gabriel that Mary would conceive the Christ child.\\n\\nUpon its recent adoption of the Gregorian Calendar, Britain has controversially followed Catholic Europe's example and changed New Year's Day to January 1st - so now Easter will be celebrated around the anniversary of the First Council of Nicaea - and meaning that the British year now matches that of it's continental neighbours. Rumour has it that this change is also partly motivated by embarrassment, as having a calendar out of step with almost everyone else was causing problems for both traders and generals alike!\\n\\nThe upshot of this change is that the average man is suddenly concerned with the whereabouts of the "missing" eleven days he feels have been taken away from him, and the injustice of having his life unreasonably and inexplicably "shortened" against his will!

While searching for a better kind of steel to use in his workings, clockmaker Benjamin Huntsman has discovered a process for producing harder, purer steel than any currently in production.\\n\\nWhile the details are a closely guarded secret, it is known that the method involves heating and cooling iron in large clay crucibles. To obtain a cheaper source for the coke that fuels his furnaces, Mr. Huntsman has recently relocated to Handsworth, near Sheffield. Certainly the cutlery makers of that town will benefit from the close proximity of this high quality "crucible steel".\\n\\nHowever, it should be noted that whereas this is an innovation in the West, steel of this quality - or "wootz" - has been produced in India for generations. Indeed, the Indian process uses crucibles in a remarkably similar way and has apparently been practiced since the fourth century.

The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has received a paper from Anders Celsius, Professor of Astronomy at Uppsala University, entitled "Observations of two persistent degrees on a thermometer".\\n\\nCelsius, already celebrated as the founder of the Uppsala Astronomical Observatory and for his detailed studies of the Aurora Borealis, proposes a scale of temperature measurement in which the boiling point of water is denoted as zero and its freezing point as one hundred.\\n\\nIn addition, Celsius has also determined that the boiling point of water changes according to atmospheric pressure, and that its freezing point is independent of outside factors.

The navy has always held supplies of Suffolk Cheese or "Suffolk Bang", a durable "flet" cheese - made from milk already skimmed for butter production. Unfortunately, being virtually inedible, it is said that "hunger can break through everything except Suffolk Cheese".\\n\\nAfter frequent complaints about it the navy has decided to move over to supplying ships with Cheshire and Gloucester Cheese instead, full-fat cheeses of greater flavour - although much more expensive and with a shorter shelf-life.

Chemistry as a science is gradually becoming as important as physics and astronomy.
